We will see where the opposition stands this time on our changes to unfair dismissal laws, which will provide many jobs, and also where they stand on support for youth pay ratesâa major issue in terms of the job market as well. Our exporters continue to perform strongly, with the annual trade outcome statement revealing a record $114 billion in exports of goods and services. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Could the minister provide the Senate with further information about how the government is committed to driving the changes needed to keep the Australian economy strong and to benefit the Australian people?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: âI was just going to say that because really what has been achieved, whilst it is excellent, is not the question for the future. The question for the future is: what further can be done? Of course, the parliament has before it reforms to our taxation system that will give great advantage to Australian business vis-a-vis its competitors to build on the solid base of low interest rates, low inflation and low debt which has enabled the achievements to date. Not only will we be giving back under this tax reform some $13 billion in much needed personal tax cuts but also the removal of the tax upon exports will make our exports more competitive and build upon the solid base that has been set. The challenge is there for the future. We have put in place a sound economic foundation to build upon the achievements of the last three years. We have the opportunity to continue to grow the Australian economy and to provide jobs for Australians who are still out of work, and it is largely up to the Labor Party whether it is prepared to be part of it. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Special Minister of State: Travel Costs

talk.start.para: âMy question without notice is directed to the Special Minister of State, Senator Ellison. Given that both Senator Minchin and Minister Fahey claim that there is no illegality in the charter claims that the minister has repaid, will the minister now table in the parliament: one, all papers related to the first departmental investigation; two, all legal advices sought on this matter; and, three, the full details of the further repayments made and the circumstances surrounding them? Further, will the minister table all of the guidelines applying to charter flights from the period 1993 to 1998?

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Special Minister of State

talk.start.para: âIt might help if by way of background I preface my answer with the fact that, for some time, there has been some uncertainty in relation to these guidelines that Senator Faulkner has referred to. In fact, this has been the comment not only of people on my side but all around the chamber. In particular, the Remuneration Tribunal indicated in December last year when it changed the guidelines that, in order to remove any ambiguity and clarify entitlements, it recognised that the taking of passengers in certain circumstances could constitute a legitimate exercise in the service of one's electorate. That was a distinct change in the rules and it was a recognition by the Remuneration Tribunal that there had been some uncertainty and ambiguity in relation to these rules. As well as that, we have also had the comments of various senators from all sides, I would submit, in relation to the uncertainty of these guidelines.

answer.para: In relation to my situation, I made a payment last year in late September and, as a result of that, then searched my records. It became apparent that a payment was due and, when I had undertaken a search of those records, I contacted the department and my senior minister and went through those instances with the Minister for Finance and Administration. I stress that I did that of my own volition and on my own initiative. This was not requested of me; it was something which I took upon myself.

Subsequent to that, the department obtained legal advice from the Attorney-General's Department and a leading private law firm. That advice was that there was some doubt as to whether the Commonwealth had a legally recoverable debt. Consequently, I was advised that no payment by me was required. Despite that, I elected to make a payment. I felt that, in my position as the Special Minister of State, it fell upon me to make that payment and, in particular, to avoid the perception that there had been some change in the rules which might suit me or some legal advice which benefited me. I wanted to make it very clear that this was not the case. In relation to the legal advice obtained, it has long been a practice that ministers do not divulge legal advice obtained by the government. That is a longstanding practice which the Labor opposition adhered to when it was in government.

I believe that I have acted appropriately as the Special Minister of State, and I have sought to clarify this matter. There has been no payment to me, and I reject the notion that there has been any repayment as such. There has been no payment to me in relation to these entitlements. I am a senator from Western Australia and I have to serve a very large state, a state which is the size of continental Europe. Of course, members and senators who have large electorates do have a charter entitlement, and that charter entitlement is so that the more remote areas of their electorate can be serviced. The charter allowance which I used was within entitlement and, as I say, my actions were entirely appropriate in the circumstances. I therefore believe that, in the circumstances, the advice is not relevant and would not normally be tabled. I can say that the costing of this matter was done by the department, and I have now paid the sum of $9,063 as a result.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, given that you are the minister in the Commonwealth responsible for the administration of parliamentary allowances and entitlements, I would have thought that it would be both in the public interest and in the interests of the parliament if the details relating to the first departmental investigation were tabled, if the second and further repayments were tabled and also if the advices were tabled. In relation to the advices, Minister, is it not true that the reason you are refusing to tableâ

âMadam President, I rise on a point of order. You have chastised Senator Faulkner on many occasions. He is again addressing the minister on this particular issue when he should be addressing you. I know you have told him a number of timesâand it is very hard for him to get it through his skullâbut could I ask you to oblige him to stand by the standing orders?
âI would ask you to address your remarks through the chair and not directly to the minister, Senator.

âThank you, Madam President. I ask the minister if it is true that the reason he is refusing to table the legal advices is that he and his colleagues have been scrabbling around desperately trying to find a legal opinion that lets the minister off the hook. Why are we not entitled to come to the conclusion in relation to this issue that, as far as this minister is concerned, he is poacher turned gamekeeper?

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Special Minister of State

talk.start.para: âI totally reject that. As I said earlier, I have made this payment in order that it is made absolutely clear that I have not taken the benefit of any legal advice or change in rules. I want that to be absolutely clear. I say that in this chamber because that is why I made that payment. It is a longstanding practice that legal advice is not tabled, and when the Labor opposition was in government it did not table legal advice it obtained.

âMy question without notice is directed to the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, Senator Alston. Given that the Howard government has adopted a clear and logically consistent position during the public debate over the issue of government ownership of Telstra, is the minister aware of other policy positions in this debate? Have these other policy positions been moving towards the stand which the Howard government has consistently taken?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âSenator Tierney is dead right. We have been utterly consistent in all of our pronouncements and policy commitments in relation to the privatisation of Telstra. In relation to 1996, of course, we were out there seeking a mandate to sell one-third of Telstra against ferocious opposition from the usual suspects. We got that through. In March 1998 the Prime Minister again announced that we would seek to go further. We then accordingly proposed in the last election campaign that we would in fact seek a staged sale of Telstra.
âHe didn't even tell you he was doing it. He treated you as a doormat, as usual.

âOur position has been crystal clear. This is where it starts to get interesting, Senator Schacht, so if I were you I would just listen. What do we have by way of contrast? We have a constantly shifting policy position designed to defend the indefensible, knowing all along that this is what every other country in the world is doing. The Labor Party in government would be no different to anyone else around the world; they would be privatising Telstra as soon as they possibly could. On Sunday Mr Beazley said:

answer.para: Labor's policy is to defend the maximum possible public ownership of Telstra.

Classic weasel words. Having studiously refrained from endorsing Mark Latham, whose book he actually launched, he then came out and said some nice words in favour of Mr Tanner, whose book he did not actually launch. What he said about Mr Tanner's idea was that it was interesting that Mr Tanner was proposing to break up Telstra. This is the union agenda, as we all know, because the unions have long said, `There aren't too many members of ours in the new and emerging areas of Telstra, but it is the infrastructureâthe network, the techs and the linesmenâwhere we have got our membership, so we want you to hang on to that.' Of course, Mr Tannerâbeing a captive of the union, like all the othersâhas gone down that path to some extent.

Mr Beazley said that Lindsay said in his book `extract the net from Telstra.' I would be amazed if Mr Tanner said `the net', but it shows that Mr Beazley does not understand the difference between the net and the infrastructure, and he said nationalise it. If you nationalise it, you would have to pay compensation on just terms. So put a number on it. It could be $5 billion, $6 billion or $8 billion, which you would immediately have to give back to Telstra shareholders. Then he says that you can have competitive arrangements. Of course, we do have competitive arrangements. Mr Beazley is clearly utterly oblivious to competition law and the way in which bottleneck theory has emerged. We do actually have high levels of competition and 25 new carriers.

Whilst Mr Beazley is out there saying those sorts of things, Mr Tanner is running a million miles away from that very policy proposition, because in an article in today's paper, which is an extract from the book, he says:

Defining what basic telecommunications capacity entails is not quite so simple in a world of rapidly changing technologies. Separating Telstra into privately owned and publicly owned companies would be a complex task.
Mr Tanner is disowning the very idea. What are we left with? Mr Beazley says this:
The past is a foreign country as far as our previous policies were concerned.

In other words, the true believers are now dilettante agnostics; they do not believe in anything any more. They were passionately opposed to Telstra, but now that is all out the window; that was the last election. Why do you need to oppose it when it comes on for debate here? Of course you do not. It is utterly opportunistic. You have no policies. Mr Beazley talks about a foreign country, but he is really parking himself offshore in wonderland where you sit and look at all these interesting policy proposals being thrown up in the air and say, `Isn't that interesting? What a good idea. Must have a think about it.' But the headline to Mr Tanner's article was, `It's time to lead the IT revolution.' Who normally does the leading in political parties? The leader. Where is Mr Beazley? He wouldn't have a clue. He is sitting there blindly endorsing proposals which people are disowning. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Special Minister of State: Travel Costs

talk.start.para: âMy question without notice is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill. I refer to the Prime Minister's revelation on Lateline on Tuesday, 9 February that he knew of Senator Ellison's repayment of charter flight costs prior to Senator Ellison's appointment as Special Minister of State. When was the Prime Minister informed and by whom? When was the Prime Minister informed of the second repayment and by whom?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: âThey are questions of detail on which I will have to seek advice.

âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Given that the Prime Minister has been informed of Senator Ellison's repayment of charter allowance, was he similarly informed of Mr McGauran's repayment prior to his reappointment as a minister? If so, when was he informed, by whom and what was the amount involved?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: âI will just correct one aspect which I thought Senator Ellison had corrected. In his instance, it is not an issue of repayment, because there was no legal debt in the first instance. It is a voluntary payment that he has chosen to make. In relation to the payment by Mr McGauran and when the Prime Minister was informed of that, that is another question of detail that I would have to check.

âMy question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer. Did the Treasurer recently hold a secret meeting with industry groups such as the BCA, ACCI and the Business Coalition for Tax Reform, as was reported in the Financial Review ? If so, did the Treasurer urge these groups to launch a new partisan public campaign against the exemption of food from the GST? Were capital gains taxes also raised as an issue at this meeting? If so, was the Prime Minister made aware of this meeting before he singled out capital gains as an issue in his public comments at the weekend?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: âIn relation to the first part of Senator Lees's question, the Treasurer meets with a very wide range of groupsâas indeed the Treasurer should. One of the Treasurer's jobs, one of the jobs on our sideâI think one of the jobs of everyone in parliamentâis to liaise closely with groups in the wider community on public policy issues. Senator Lees, I am not aware of any so-called secret meeting. If the Treasurer was meeting with people from the business groups, what I can say is: good on him. That is exactly what one would expect the Treasurer to do. It follows then that, in relation to the second part of the question, I am not aware of what was discussed at any such meeting, if such a meeting occurred.

answer.para: What I can say to you is that this government is a government of reform. This is a government that went to the election on a program of tax reform. It is a government which was quite explicit to the Australian people on what it sought to achieve with its tax reforms. I would urge the Democrats to make sure that we keep our promises on tax reform and to make sure we pass our programâthe program we went to the Australian people withâin its entirety.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, given that in the document on a new tax system you took to the election you say very clearly you do not propose to change the capital gains taxes unless they are revenue neutral, given that the government repeatedly tells us that that tax package is non-negotiable and given the evidence to the committee this morning from Chris Murphy that taking food out of the GST has no negative economic effect, can you explain why your government is apparently prepared to give ground to business on capital gains tax but not prepared to give ground to the church and welfare groups on food?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: âIn the tax package that we went to the election with, we announced that the Ralph committee would be looking at issues such as capital gains tax and, as far as I am aware, that is precisely what is happening. In relation to the second part of your question, there would be major problems for the tax package, as you are aware, if food were extracted from that tax package and made GST free. I think the experience in other countries around the world has shown that it would lead to major issues of compliance and major costs of compliance. What the Democrats have to do, as I said, is to make sure that we keep our promises on the tax package. That is what you should do. I would have thought it was the traditional role of the Australian Democrats to do that. (Time expired)
âI would remind the minister of the necessity to address the chair.

âMy question without notice is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is the minister aware that the Prime Minister has stated that he was only following public service recommendations when he watered down his ministerial code of conduct? Is it a fact that the advice referred to by the Prime Minister was the incoming government brief prepared by departments on the basis of the stated intentions of the parties prior to the election? Is it a fact that this advice was a direct result of comments attributed to the Prime Minister in an article by Mike Seccombe during the federal election campaign? Will the minister now correct the gross untruth disseminated by the Prime Minister in trying to pretend that the watering down of his code had its origin in the bureaucracy?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: âNot surprisingly, my brief does not specifically address the question that Senator Faulkner raises, but I also do not accept his description of a watering down of the guidelines. They have been restructured in a way to better reflect contemporary circumstances. Within government there are people who have had successful careers before parliament and have accumulated wealthâsomething that the Labor Party hates, seeing that most of the other side come from a trade union background or occasionally have been party officials. But our side of politics better reflects the broad range of occupationsâ
âLawyers!
âYeah, lawyers.
âOrder! There are too many interjections
âIt better reflects the broad range of occupations within the Australian community.
âLawyers!
âSenator Carr, stop shouting.

âYes, some lawyers, some teachers, some doctorsâa whole range. We don't apologise for that. The question is, then, how an incoming minister should appropriately deal with that wealth so that there cannot be an issue of either conflict of interest or perceived conflict of interest. The Prime Minister has now put down a code of conduct that will ensure that such interests are at arms length but at the same time ensuring that the family of the relevant member or senator is not disadvantaged.
âHow can you keep a straight face?

âI welcome Senator Bolkus. It is good to see you here today. It is a sensible, rational set of rules that can provide the safeguards that are necessary to demonstrate public probity. As I said, they reflect the circumstances that indicate that it is not just trade unionists that are now members of the Australian ministry.

âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the minister now admit that it was not the bureaucracy's idea to dilute the code; in fact, it was Mr Howard's own idea? Won't the minister concede that the revised code represents a very significant slide in the standard that was demanded of ministers and represents a further nail in the coffin of the Prime Minister's now laughable claim that he made prior to the 1996 election that he, John Howard, would raise standards in Australian political life?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: âNo. The Prime Minister demands high standards, and this code of conduct will give the public confidence that such high standards will be maintained. In relation to the source of advice, of course the Prime Minister takes advice from his bureaucracy and from other sources as well. I am sure that all of that was properly taken into account in the development of these new contemporary guidelines.

âMy question is addressed to the Leader of the Government. It arises from the fact that Australia Day is celebrated on the day rather than as part of a long weekend. Is it not a fact that, if you were to take a poll of or have a yarn with ordinary working Australians, you would find that most of them want to see a return to the old Australia Day weekend? Is it not a fact that the uniform approach resulted from former Prime Minister Hawke and some sort of belief in `loyalty to Australia'? Doesn't the current Prime Minister feel that it would be good if we had a comfortable and relaxed population? Is it not a fact also that that population would be far more thankful and loyal to Australia if they could enjoy the Australia Day long weekend? What about the disruption to small business that occurs as a result of abolishing the Australia Day long weekend and instead celebrating Australia Day on 26 January?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: âCertainly we want a more comfortable and relaxed Australian communi ty, and we are pleased that, through low interest ratesâ
âThat's rightâwhen the Government front bench has a big share portfolio.
âSenator Carr, cease shouting.

âfalling unemployment, low inflation and lower debt, there is a better chance of achieving those objectives. In relation to the time for relaxation that is related to the celebration of Australia Day, I am sure that that is the sort of matter on which the Prime Minister would wish me to come back with a considered reply. I must say that I myself have not been giving it a lot of thought just of late, but no doubt the Prime Minister has and would have a view that he would like to express to Senator Harradine and the Senate. I will get that response and bring it back as soon as possible.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Veterans' Affairs: Goods and Services Tax Mail-out

talk.start.para: âMy question is addressed to the Minister for Family and Community Services. Minister, can you confirm that you requested use of the database of Veterans' Affairs pensioners to post out GST junk mail in the lead-up to the last federal election campaign? Is it a fact that Dr Johnston, Secretary of the Department of Veterans' Affairs, stated, `I and my minister would have preferred to have been aware of it before it occurred.' Can it be true that the minister requested this mail-out without any prior notification to, let alone seeking the agreement of, her colleague the Minister for Veterans' Affairs or his department? How does the minister justify this gross breach of both common courtesy and the law?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âAs Senator Schacht knows full well, he has been given substantial answers to those questions in the Senate estimates committee. So he is trying to beat a dead cat. The answer to Senator Schacht's first question is: no, I did not request the use of the DVA database. In fact, from the answer that was given in the Senate estimates committee, Senator Schacht, if he had been listening to other people rather than the sound of his own voice, would have learned that the procedure for this mail-out of the tax reform information for pensioners was for people on income support, whether in Veterans' Affairs or the Social Security portfolio. They were people who were on income support payments such as age pension and service pension, not in receipt of disability payments. These are all details that Senator Schacht was given the other day. In addition, it was practice which had been followed over many years, including innumerable times by his own government, that the database was used for such mail-outs.
âWithout consultation?
âOrder! Senator Schacht, there is an appropriate time to ask a supplementary question.
âIt has never happened before, and you know it.
âSenator Faulkner!

âThe departmental secretary did not say it had never happened before; I think he said that he would have a look and take it on notice. Senator Faulkner, you were not present, I think, at the time. The important thing to understand is that Centrelink now, and Social Security in the past, maintained a database for the purposes of age pension news. That included the DVA database as well for service pensioners. Periodically, as the Senate estimates committee was told, DVA updates the database, previously for Social Security and now for Centrelink. There was no special treatment on this occasion; it was the normal procedure. There was not an age pension news due to go out at the time, and it was important thatâwith the confusion that was being created, partly by some members of the oppositionâpeople who needed to get information about changes to age pension and compensation arrangements through the changes to the tax system should get that information rather than disinformation which so frequently comes from the mouths of members of the opposition.

answer.para: Therefore, that was the procedure. There was not a gross breach. It might have been helpful for the minister to have had information ahead of time. But Senator Schacht should recall that, during the Veterans' Affairs estimates, Dr Johnston said he believed that he was informed or his department was informed as it was about to go out, and he was going to check those facts.

talk.start.para: âOr after it went out.

âHe corrected himself and said that he would get advice and answer the question on notice. That is something which I am sure Senator Schacht would know if he had been listening to others instead of only to himself.

âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, you say that you did not make the decision to send out the letter. Who did then make it; who was responsible for the decision to mail out the letter to the veterans? Will you take this opportunity to publicly apologise to your colleague for not letting him know that this letter was going out, and to publicly apologise to his department? And, more to the point, will you take this opportunity to apologise to the 350,000 veterans who received the unsolicited GST junk mail in flagrant breach of their privacy?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âI thank Senator Schacht for his supplementary question. My office asked the department to prepare a mail-out to the people on the age pension news database.
âYour office!

âThis information was provided by Dr Rosalky at the Family and Community Services estimates hearings last week. It is all there on the Hansard for anybody to read. I am not misrepresenting the situation. I think it would pay Senator Schacht to go back and read that.

âMy question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources. Is the government's industry policy focused on creating jobs through investment and innovation? Is the minister aware of alternative policy proposals? What would be the impact of these policies on investment and jobs?

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Industry, Science and Resources

talk.start.para: âI thank Senator Chapman for his question. Senator Chapman is rightâthe government's policy is very clearly focused on programs to support the key drivers of growth, higher living standards and jobs. They are about supporting innovation; they are about attracting a greater level of investment to Australia and greater market access for Australian businesses. Our industry policy is about maximising the competitiveness of Australian businesses. That is against the background of getting the macro-economic fundamentals right: budget surpluses, low inflation, low interest rates, sustainable growth and the one big area left untouched by Labor, tax reform.

answer.para: The opposition's approach to industry policy is very interesting. We had Simon Crean in the job of shadow minister for the first 2Â½ years. He could not think of any bright new ideas, so he advocated a return to the 1970sâhighly interventionist, backward looking, dead-end 1970s policies. There has been a refreshing change in the opposition. Bob McMullan now has the job, and one of his first tasks was to abandon the Simon Crean approach. But, regrettably, nothing has been put in its place. It is just a blank page now. I gather that Mr Beazley has told the caucus there will not be any policies until the conference in 2001. So you are a blank page for another couple of years.

This morning in the Melbourne Age we had Bob McMullan, of all people, actually criticising the government for not moving faster on the reform of capital gains taxâa capital gains tax system created by Paul Keating. I do welcome Bob McMullan's conversion to the cause of reform of capital gains tax, and that is very much part of the Ralph review, but it is a bit rich for the industry spokesman for the ALP, when the ALP's election policy was not only to keep the existing capital gains tax but also to make it retrospective, to attack us for not moving fast enough to reform it.

Labor want to keep the wholesale sales taxâthe most anti-industry policy imaginable, the policy that is most biased against the manufacturing industry in this country. That is the one policy you have, and you want to keep it. You also have a policy of opposing $13,000 million worth of personal income taxes. You are hopelessly divided on industry policy. We have the Crean interventionists on the one hand, and now we have the Lindsay Tanner and Mark Latham economic realists who have suddenly popped up. Lindsay Tanner roundly criticised the Crean approach in his book when he said:

Instinctively interventionist, the Australian Left is now functioning in a theoretical vacuum in economic and industry policy . . . The risk we now face is the prospect of return to the 1970s, with policy prescriptions based on ad-hoc remedial actions, instinctive impulses and occasional fads.
Mark Latham was even more critical last year when he said of your industry policy:
Now federal Labor is offering corporate Australia a break from competition and a chance to slip back onto the public teat.

Those were his words, not mine. As the government industry minister, I certainly welcome the conversion of both Mark Latham and Lindsay Tanner to the government's approach to industry policy. If you read what both of them have said, it is a clear endorsement of the government's approach to industry policy. I do think this is an area where bipartisanship would be a very good thing. The big question is, will Mr Beazley have the courage to support the only two people in his party who seem to have any policy ideas at all?

talk.start.para: âMy question is directed to Senator Herron in his capacity representing the Minister for Health and Aged Care. Can the minister explain why he told the Australian Cancer Society that their $800,000 grant was to be cancelled because the government had been angered by its lobbying for increased resources for anti-smoking campaigns targeted at young people? Does the minister believe it is appropriate to use the weapon of public funding to browbeat respected, independent community organisations into signing on to the government's political agenda?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âI thank Senator Evans for the question. I am sure I can respond on the minister's behalf to say that he does not use the Labor Party's standards in relation to browbeating community organisations to follow the party line. I totally reject that implication in the question that was asked of me. However, there is no answer in the briefs that I have been given in relation to the Australian Cancer Society, and I will send that on to the minister for an answer for Senator Evans.

âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. My question asked the minister why he told the Cancer Society that, not why Dr Wooldridge did. Can he assure us that the government's vindictiveness has nothing to do with the Australian Cancer Society's distribution of a leaflet which was critical of the government in the electorate of Casey where the health minister, Dr Wooldridge, was a Liberal Party candidate? Is that not related to the decision?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âI have had no communication with the Australian Cancer Society, but I will check the records to see whether my memory is deficient in that regard. I am sure that it is not. Senator Evans appears to have some communication. I do not recall writing to the Australian Cancer Society. I thought the question related to the minister, but if he believes that it relates to me I will check the record and get back to him.

âMy question is addressed to the Special Minister of State, Senator Ellison. I ask the minister: given that the Prime Minister is prepared to consider a second question to be put in the referendum on the republic, would the government consider using the wording of the resolution moved by the late Senator Bonner and passed unanimously by the Senate on 20 February 1975? I have asked an attendant to provide a copy of that resolution to you.

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Special Minister of State

talk.start.para: âIn its communique last year the Constitutional Convention recommended that a preamble be put to the people of Australia and that that preamble be dependent on Australia becoming a republic. Part of that preamble included reference to the indigenous people of Australia and their prior custodianship of Australia. The question of the preamble, how it is worded and how it is put to the people of Australia is under consideration by the government and by the referendum task force, of which I am a member. The government realises that this is a very important question, and it is certainly one which will be the subject of consultation once we release the legislation, and it will be available for scrutiny by all parties.
âWhen's that?
âI hope that it will be in the very near future. But I can say to Senator Woodley that I will take up his question with the referendum task force.
âI thank the Minister for that answer. It may be useful, Madam President, if the Senate heard again the wording of that resolution so that I can be sure that the minister isâ
âThis should be a supplementary question, Senator.
âYes, I realise that. My supplementary question is whether this is the wording that the minister, and I think it is critical that he do so, will in fact put to that task group:

question.para: . . . the Senate accepts the fact that the indigenous people of Australia, now known as Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders, were in possession of this entire nation prior to the 1788 First Fleet landing at Botany Bay, and urges the Australian Government to admit prior ownership of the said indigenous people and introduce legislation to compensate the people now known as Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders for dispossession of their land.
Minister, that wording of Senator Bonner's motion was acceptable to all parties in 1975. Can you ask the government if it would be acceptable now?

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Special Minister of State

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I have undertaken to Senator Woodley that I will convey his comments to the government, and I will do so.

âMy question without notice is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill. Will the minister confirm reports that the first the Department of Finance and Administration heard of the $100 million Victorian gas relief fund was via a press release from the Prime Minister? Does it therefore follow that no proper costings or advice were sought from DOFA, despite the fact that they were to be the administrative body for that fund? Given this shambles, is it surprising that more than four months after the fund's announcement only $7 million has been distributed to those affected? Does this explain why the Victorian government is attempting to grab $42 million from the Commonwealth for gas relief? Isn't it just a further indication that the entire package was merely a last-minute attempt by a desperate Prime Minister to obtain political mileage out of the Victorian gas crisis?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: âFar from it; it was a response to an emergency situation in Victoria where a growing number of Victorians were becoming distressed by their personal and their business circumstances, and the Prime Minister believed that it warranted urgent action. The figure that was placed as a maximum was an estimate, that is true. As it has turned out, only a relatively small proportion of that sum was expendedâa little over the figure that Senator Carr referred to in his question.

answer.para: In some ways that is good news, obviously, because the announcement of the funding was intended to be a safeguard for those particularly in need. The fact that fewer suffered loss is something for which we should all be thankful, and the fact that it will cost the Australian taxpayer less is something for which we also should be thankful. So I would have thought that Senator Carr would recognise that to be a good thing, as he ought to recognise the willingness of the Prime Minister to respond to particularly anxious Australians in difficult circumstances as something that should be applauded.

There is no question of `grabbing' any other part of that sum. Certainly the Victorian government has made submissions to the Commonwealth government seeking support in relation to gas infrastructure, which they say will better ensure that such a disaster does not again occur, and that will be considered by the government according to the normal timetable. So the outcome was fairly good all round, I think, in this instance, and Senator Carr ought to be pleased with that circumstance.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Rather than being an indication that the losses were in fact less than anticipated, is it not a fact that the $7 million figure that has been quoted as being the amount of money that was expended on claims for compensation indicates that this was in fact a cynical political exercise by this government, that there was not any attempt to seriously address the real needs of the Victorian community, and that this program was designed to save the hide of the Liberal government rather than to compensate Victorians for the gas crisis?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: âI would have thought Senator Carr would have been more concerned about anxious Victorians in those difficult times. If he cast his mind back, he would recall that there was growing distress within the Victorian community. Certainly, yes, there were strict safeguards within the announcement of the Prime Minister, and he would not apologise for that. He is responsible for public money and would not want it to be unnecessarily spent. But it did give the public greater confidence in a time of need. It met urgent losses that were in fact incurred. It did not cost as much as was anticipated might be the case, but that is a good thing.
âPeople didn't know about it.
âThey certainly did know about it because we advertised it, and you condemned that as well, Senator Carr.

âMy question without notice is to Senator Newman, the Minister for Family and Community Services. The coalition has broadly based policies to strengthen and sustain both families and relationships. Will the minister outline any new initiatives which demonstrate the government's continuing commitment towards both the social and economic welfare of all Australians?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âIt is refreshing to get questions from this side of the chamber because they focus on policy issues as distinct from those of the opposition, who seem to be in policy-free zones. This government, as all Australians would recognise, has been particularly focused on improving both the social and the economic status of Australia's families since we came into government nearly three years ago. I only need to remind the Senate of the family tax initiative which was introduced immediately we came into government, which was a major help to Australia's families.

answer.para: That was followed, in August, by the announcement of the family tax changesâthe family paymentsâwhich will reduce poverty traps for families, particularly those working families on relatively low incomes. This is a substantial improvement in their situation, as are tax cuts for those who are in the work force, and there is health insurance help et cetera. So in many ways the financial circumstances have been focused on very strongly. It is important not to forget that, at the same time, this government has been responsible for a substantial reduction in the cost of a family's mortgage because of low interest rates. You put all those things together and you can see that, financially, families have a much better chance than they did when we came into government.

Importantly, there have been a couple of initiatives over the last couple of months which I think bear drawing to the attention of the Senate. One is the announcement by the Prime Minister last December that the youth homelessness pilot scheme would be expanded to 100 services around Australia, with a substantial increase in expenditure. It will draw community organisations into partnership with government to try and make sure that the reasons for homelessness are prevented to the extent possible. Where homelessness is a fact, we will try to deal with the crisis but also, at the same time, we will try to involve parents in all these activities. That is something which Australian parents have been wanting to see for a long time.

Yesterday I announced the Relate Program, which is focused on trying to help people of all ages with their relationships. This is particularly important, of course, for the group of 18- to 24-year-old Australians who believe most firmly in marriage as a life-long com mitment and, yet, are the ones most concerned that their relationships might fail. I think it is also true to say that a very high proportion of the people who have actually found their way to relationship services in the past say that they have learnt new skills to apply to their current relationship, that what they have learnt in the training courses will be of lasting value and, importantly, that they would recommend marriage and relationship education to someone else. But a survey was done which, sadly, found that something like a quarter of couples did not know who provides services and where to find them. Many senators would realise that it is provided by Centacare Australia, by Relationships Australia and by Family Services Australia.

I would be delighted to give the Senate more information if Senator Payne would like to ask me more about this subject. There is so much to talk about. One of the concerns that I have is that about 50 per cent of marriages are celebrated by secular celebrants and their referral rate to pre-marriage education courses has been particularly low. One of the purposes of the Relate Program is to help civil marriage celebrants refer more people to courses by providing them with information about the services available in their local area.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question of the minister. I was fortunate to attend the Prime Minister's announcement of the extension of the youth homelessness pilot in Sydney last year and I would be interested, Minister, if you could outline any further initiatives on that area and, through you Madam President, in relation to the launch of Relate yesterday, whether there are any further steps the government is taking in that area.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âThe Relate Program recognises that there are some very significant points in people's lives where they need to hone their skills to maintain a happy and a stable relationship. There are courses about becoming a couple in the first place; on adjusting to life with your first babyâtraumatic for most of us, I think; the role of fathers and their family involvementâwhich has been neglected so much in the past but, thankfully, many fathers are now wanting to take their place in the caring role; combining work and family lifeâwhich is no longer an issue for women but an issue for mothers and fathers; the complications of that combination of work and family life; and the very relevant issue of dealing with blended families and stepchildren. These courses are designed to help people with those circumstances in their lives. It cannot all be done by government, so community organisations are being subsidised to provide these services. It is up to the individuals themselves, to the marriage celebrants and to the community organisations, as well as the government, to turn this thing around. (Time expired)

âMy question is to the Leader of Government in the Senate, Senator Hill, representing the Prime Minister. Is the minister aware of reported comments by the former Senator, Jim Short, and current backbencher, Senator Brian Gibson, that neither of them would have had to resign if the Prime Minister's revised code of conduct had been in place in 1996? Can the minister confirm that this would be the effect of the debased code of conduct if a minister made a decision which materially affected a company in which the minister had a shareholding, as was the case in the Gibson and Short cases?
âI want you to know I am on your side, no matter how many times you gag me.
âOrder! Senator Conroy, you have been persistently interjecting today.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: âAs I said earlier today, the Prime Minister makes no apology for the fact that he demands the highest of standards and that the codes of conduct, both for this government and the previous government, are highly demanding. There is no question about that at all. The circumstances of the resignations of both former Senator Short and Senator Gibson were unfortunate in that neither gained any personal advantage whatsoever. Both are extremely proper and highly respected parliamentarians and Australians and the fact that they were prepared to resign in those circumstances is a great credit to them and something which we recognise with appreciation. The guidelines will be adhered to by ministers of this government and the Prime Minister, as in the past, will ensure that they are adhered to.

âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. I note, Senator Hill, that you were not prepared to actually answer the question put to you about whether they are right in saying that a debased code would have let them off. In view of that, would you please try to answer that question and not duck, weave and hide from it? Would you also answer this question: in light of the likely outcome of the gelded code of conduct, when will the Howard government apologise to Mr Short and to Senator Gibson?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: âYou must have spent a lot of time thinking of that one, Cookie. It is not my job to apply any set of circumstances to these guidelines. That is the Prime Minister's job. He will apply circumstances to the current guidelines if and as is required. That is his job. He has done it in the past, and he will not shy away from that. He will continue to be determined that his government, the second government, will uphold the high standards of the government of the past. Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âSenator Evans asked me whether I had written to the Australian Cancer Society. I have checked with my office. As I said, I have no memory nor do we have a record of a letter to the Australian Cancer Society. In relation to the other matter, I will get back to him with a response from the minister.
âI move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for the Environment and Heritage (Senator Hill), to a question without notice asked by Senator Faulkner today, relating to senators' interests and the Prime Minister's `Guide on Key Elements of Ministerial Responsibility'.

Many media commentators and editorialists have recognised that the latest prime ministerial code is a very significant dilution of the requirements on ministers in the Commonwealth parliament regarding conflict of interestâconflict of public duties and their private interests. Of course the Prime Minister still continues with the pathetic and the untruthful excuse that he is only following advice from the Commonwealth Public Service in relation to bringing down his new code of conduct. The truth is that this dilution in standards is just the most recent of a long line of failures, a long line of falling standards, on the part of this government; and the propriety of this government has been very seriously questioned not only in the parliament but also by the Australian public.

Over the past three years, standards of public accountability have fallen because of this Prime Minister's either unwillingness or inability to enforce his own code of conduct. There was nothing wrong with the code of conduct that John Howard tabled in the House of Representatives when he first became Prime Minister in 1996. The failure was John Howard's own failure to enforce the code. We need a tough code and we need a Prime Minister who is tough enough to enforce a tough code. We have neither. Now the Special Minister of State, Senator Ellison, is being questioned over the issue of repayment of charter entitlements. This is the minister who is responsible for the administration of parliamentary entitlements in the government. He is the person responsible for the administration of allowances and entitlements.

He was not willing in question time today to say that he will table, for the benefit of the parliament and the public, all the details related to the first repayment of $1,027.29. He has indicated he is not willing to provide details of the repayment of $9,063 to the Commonwealth, and he said he will not table legal advices. I think we are entitled to come to the conclusion that the reason the minister will not front up with these legal advices is that ministers and the government are scrab bling around desperately making three or four attempts to get legal advice that lets the Special Minister of State off the hook on this issue. That is simply not good enough.

We are concerned that the situation with the new Special Minister of State is that we have a poacher turned gamekeeper appointed by the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, to this very sensitive portfolio with responsibility for the administration of parliamentary allowances and entitlements. Senator Ellison's case is probably a very pale imitation of the parliamentarian who set the example for the misuse of charter flights entitlements. We await the outcome of the Mellors report and the Kennedy report, which we have been questioning about in Senate estimates.

Mr Peter McGauran, who has been resurrected to the front bench because of the paucity of National Party talent, also has an awful lot of questions to answer. We want a comprehensive explanation of the situation relating to Mr McGauran as well as Senator Ellison put on the public record. A full disclosure in relation to Mr McGauran now ought to be coming forward from the Prime Minister. You will not see the issue of standards and accountability and propriety disappear while ever this evidence of rorts and abuse of public moneys continues. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âIt is interesting that the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate has raised this issue from the Labor Party perspective. The Labor Party when in government had no code of conduct whatsoever. There was no tabled code of conduct. One does not have to go far back to remember some of the conflicts of interests that happened. For example, Alan Griffiths, a Labor member, owned a sandwich shop while Minister for Industry. That was a huge conflict which caused great problems for him in the end. Graham Richardson, who was a director of 2HD while a minister, did not declare his interests. Graham Richardson also used his position as a minister to try to influence the President of the Marshall Islands on behalf of his cousin, Greg Symons.

speech.para: John Dawkins's mother owned Bell shares while Holmes a Court was trying to take over BHP. Bob Hawke was a personal friend of Sir Peter Abeles when Abeles was trying to crush the pilots union. Bob Hawke used his personal position as PM to collect $1 million from four WA business leaders at the gold tax lunch. The list goes on and on and on. The difference with the code of conduct that Prime Minister Howard has now set in place is that it takes into account the situation as it is today. The Labor Party would dearly love to disfranchise anyone who has been successful or not a trade unionist from coming into the parliament of Australia. There should be no penalty associated with anyone purely and simply because they are successful.

The difference is that this government has made sure that things like shares are more available to Australians. Approximately 750,000 Australians have entered the share market for the first time in the last eight months. Since 1995, a total of 2.3 million Australians have invested in the share market for the first time. In less than four years more than one in 10 adult Australians have become shareholders for the first time. What this government has done is try to encourage more and more people to become shareholders. Therefore, we should not penalise people for doing so and then say, `You cannot enter parliament until such time as you get rid of every asset that you have possibly got.'

One only needs to look at the registers of senators' and members' interests at the moment. Have a look at former ministers. What have they done with their incomes? Where have they hidden their incomes? One can only ask the question because the register clearly does not identify where former senators have stashed 13 years of ministerial salaries.

talk.start.para: âOh, dear, dear!
âYou might go, `Dear, dear, dear.'
âWhat about spending it?

âOh, they are big spenders, are they? Senator Carr says that they are big spenders and they have spent it all. It is a good socialist attitude to say, `Yes, you just spend over $100,000 a year for 13 years and have no assets whatsoever.' The total share ownership in Australia now stands at 40.3 per cent of the Australian adult population. Yet the Labor Party are saying that we should not have share ownership.

speech.para: With regard to Senator Ellison, there is a very distinct point in his case that the Labor Party cannot get their brains around. Unfortunately, most of the journalists cannot get their brains around it either. Senator Ellison did not personally get one red cent out of any of those airline charters. There was not one single solitary charter that was outside entitlement. There was not one single solitary flight that was not meant to be taken.

It was interesting to note at question time today the cheer squad behind Senator Ray and Senator Faulkner when they were asking those questions. I think it is now up to the Labor Party to examine each and every one of their own histories as to what they have done, because it was the Labor Party that also went to the minister and expressed concerns about the ambiguity and the lack of clarity in the rules that have now been cleared up by the Minister for Finance and Administration. So I suggest the Labor Party has a long hard look at itself. Senator Ellison did not benefit personally one red cent. There is not one skerrick of rort about what he did. He has voluntarily paid back money when he did not have to do so. It should be taken into account in that form. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âSenator Hill's answer to Senator Faulkner's question today bordered on the vacuous, the glib and almost the slimy. He was asked this: on what basis did the Prime Minister change the code of conduct? If you look at his answer in the other place, the Prime Minister said that he acted on departmental advice on the incoming government brief. There is the real distortion in all this. There is the real dissembling. The fact is that the incoming brief for a government was based on government stated policies during the campaign.

speech.para: The fact is that Mr Howard did flag the watering down of the code of conduct during the campaign. I read an extensive article by Mr Mike Seccombe in the Sydney Morning Herald to that effect. Any competent Public Service would have picked up Mr Howard's views and put them in the incoming government brief. That would have been the advice based on Mr Howard's comments. Mr Howard's attempted justification that he was acting on the advice of the bureaucracy is absolute nonsense. The bureaucracy was acting on the basis of Mr Howard's views. So he cannot justify the changes to the ministerial code from what was in the incoming brief to the government.

Senator Knowles boldly says that there were no such governing principles when Labor was in government. I suggest Senator Knowles goes back and gets a copy of the cabinet handbook, where all the restrictions in terms of conflict of interest and behavioural requirements were listed. They were listed in the cabinet handbook. They also existed in letters sent to ministers when they first became ministers explaining what matters they had to declare and how they should declare them. For those in the know, the guide to ministerial responsibility was not written by Mr Howard. It was written by the then deputy secretary of PM&Câ

talk.start.para: âDrawing on all public documents.

âYes, drawing on all public documents, and basically does not vary from the ministerial guide back in the cabinet handbook. It is exactly the same standards placed on the parliament with a great amount of publicity by John Howard and then never, ever enforced.

speech.para: There are always going to be difficulties with people who own assets and shares, et cetera, that could conflict with their ministerial responsibility. That is why we have a register in the Senate where people can see what they own. What we found in the last parliament was that they were not all declared. That is what caused so many difficulties in this regard. But for Senator Hill to argue that the code has not been watered down is nothing more than a joke. Of course the code has been watered down. Let the Liberal Party at least attempt, like Senator Knowles did today, to justify the watering down. Do not blame the public servants. Do not say that you were acting on Public Service advice when that is patent nonsense if you were relying on the incoming government brief. It just will not stand up.

The reason why Mr Howard has taken such a high fall on this matter is that he puffed himself up and pretended that the incoming government would be more moral than the previous government. The fact is that it is probably more immoral than the previous government. I don't think there is any doubt about that, with all the cases that have come to light.

A final point, regarding Senator Ellison, has been raised. I have some advice for Senator Ellison which is straightforward. Senator Ellison has made claims in this chamber that he committed no illegality, that it was all based on confusion. My advice to Senator Ellison is that this issue will plague him as long as people think there is a cover-up. This issue will drive and ruin his career. If, as he claimed, he has acted with total propriety, he needs to do three things to put the issue behind him. Firstly, he should table the departmental report on the first issueâthat he has repaid the money and the department has accepted his explanation. He should put that down, put that behind him. Secondly, he should table the legal advices. It is not right for him to say today that you never table legal advices. Sometimes you do, sometimes you don't.

Thirdly, he should put down a full statement about the circumstances of his second repayment. If he does that, he puts the issue behind him. People won't accuse him of covering up. But as long as none of that material is available, those accusations will continue. I doubt he has committed a hanging offence. I don't accept the rather vacuous explanation we had today, but I don't think it is a hanging offence. Put it on the table and move on. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThe ALP's fascination with the ministerial code of conduct amazes me. We can be sure of one thing: Senator Ray won't be in this place at the time the Labor Party ever have to implement a code of conduct. It will be one hell of a long time, Senator Ray, when you have no leadership, no policies and no ideas, before you will ever have to imple ment a ministerial code of conduct. Senator Faulkner introduced his taking notice of the answer given by Senator Hill in relation to the code of conduct but then moved on to talk about the repayment by Senator Ellison of the money that he said he was prepared to repayâalthough, to use his own words, there was no requirement for him to do so. That differs significantly from the attitude of Labor Party members when they were in government and also when they have been in opposition. We have had admissions in the past from Labor senators that, although they hadn't legally broken any rules, morally they had. I don't know that any of that money has ever been repaid to the government at any stage.

speech.para: When it comes to the guidelines, Labor's Senator Mark Bishop himself, a newer member of this place, agreed that the guidelines were vague. These were the guidelines that were in place all the time that the Labor Party was in power, from 1983 to 1996. They were `vague'. Senator Mark Bishop, one of your own senators, said that the guidelines were vague. He is quoted as saying that he understood that it was acceptable to fill empty seats on charter flights if the purpose of the flight was for electoral business.

In the case of Senator Ellison, not one cent of any money that he has paid back to the department was ever of benefit to him personally. He has never had one dollar of personal benefit from any of the situations that he has found himself in. Yet he said that because of his special position as Minister of State and the person in charge of administering these guidelines, in order to clear even the remotest possibility that there was any form of conflict of interest or any mis-spending of the electorate's money, he was prepared to repay that $9,000.

Not only did Senator Bishop say that the guidelines were vague; Senator Murray from the Australian Democrats, also from Western Australia, said that the guidelines were quite vague. He said that he knew of one who had breached a charter allowance and claimed that it was inadvertent, or as a result of not knowing the rulesâthat it was an unwitting mistakeâand therefore the money was repaid. To the best of my knowledge, when I first came into this place in 1992 I also was unaware of the extent of the guidelines which supposedly existed for the taking of people on charter flights. A number of my colleagues have said that at the time of their entry into the Senate they had no idea of how the guidelines were to be applied.

So in the case of Senator Ellison there was no illegality whatsoever in the things that he did in relation to flying and using charter flights. But in order to make sure that there was absolutely no public perception of anything that could possibly have gone wrong, Senator Ellison has agreed to voluntarily repay that money.

When it comes to the ministerial code of conduct, it is obvious that the people on the other side of this chamber are very concerned about what happens to the shares that are owned by government ministers, ministers who are prepared to invest in Australiaâmuch more than we have ever seen from anybody on the other side. Very few Labor senators have ever been prepared to invest in shares or invest in Australia. We can note that by reading the Register of Senators' Interests. I don't know what they do with their money. Some of them have been ministers for quite some time. How they hide any returns they may have got or any savings they may have made while ministers, I have no idea. But the one thing they don't do is invest in Australia by way of investing in public companiesâexcept, of course, for Senator McKiernan, who was quite pleased to take up some Telstra shares when they came on the market. I forget the other one. It was possibly Senator Murphy, but I stand corrected if it wasn't. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI begin by drawing to Senator Ferguson's attention the facts in regard to the issue of the old guidelines that operated regarding the charter travel of members of parliament. Those guidelines made it absolutely clear who could travel. That was the senator, his or her spouse, their staff or other MPs. They were absolutely clear in regard to that matter. Therefore, there should be no confusion or attempts to draw red herrings across things.

speech.para: The public is naturally very cynical and, of course, disappointed at the way in which governments have behaved in recent times. In the last parliament, in particular, there was a serious issue raised about the level of government integrity. Naturally, this cynicism is not just confined to the work of government. We see public attitudes in regard to the way in which the churches operate, the way in which the law operates and, of course, the way business operates. There is a deep and abiding concern being expressed about the apparent fall in ethical standards.

However, the difference in regard to this government is that, in 1996, the Prime Minister made it clear, in the most sanctimonious of styles, that new standards were going to be set, that there would be a new model of integrity in government. Of course, we saw that this new standard was very sick in the last parliament. Towards the end of that parliament, he indicated that these new codes of conduct were just guidelines, that they should not be regarded as the immovable principles that he first established.
What we saw a week ago, however, was that this whole process, these guidelines, were finally laid to rest by the ministerial code in the person of `Penthouse Pete'âMr Reith indicatingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! Senator Carr, please refer to honourable members in the other house by their correct titles and names.

âThe Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business slipped in very late on Friday afternoon, 9 February and laid down a whole series of government documents. One of those documents was this new ministerial code. No fanfare, no prior warning, no circulation, no discussion, no consultation, not even a decent burial from this undertaker who, of course, is now trying to present that this government's new policy is more realistic and more expedient.

speech.para: The question of expedience is very much on the mind of this government when it comes to addressing these issues. We are entitled to ask why it was necessary to change these codes of conduct that the Prime Minister had indicated had such a pride of place in the formation of the new government. Quite clearly, this government had a choice to make. It had a choice to make between principle and shame. This government chose shame simply because the price of principle was getting too high; the cost of shame and humiliation was quite clearly more acceptable.

The government's code of conduct is now characterised by shame and embarrassment. The shambles created by the various shifts in position that the Prime Minister has initiated essentially arise from the very weakness of this government when it comes to the question of principle itself. Quite clearly, the price of principle was far too high for this government. It was able to be demonstrated that six ministers and, of course, many of his close personal friends had not fulfilled the requirements that the government had entered into, had breached the ministerial code of conduct and could not be sustained in the ministry.

That position, of course, was quickly changed and the government now finds itself presenting a new set of guidelines which quite clearly are totally inadequate. Who of us could possibly believe that this government's new codes of conduct would not allow for a situation where ministers can convert their private wealth to adult children and can continue to enrich themselves? Who is to suggest that they have instantly forgotten what shares they had? Who is to suggest that they would not consult with their children about the changes in the stock market? Who is to suggest that they have the capacity to transfer shares back into their ownership once they have left office? Who is to suggest for a moment that ministersâunlike the rest of the people who actually engage in the share marketâhave a direct capacity to make decisions in government about the value of shares?

It is no wonder that the public is extremely cynical about the way in which this government has treated these basic questions of principle and integrity. As I have said, the choice was very clear for the governmentâthe choice between principle and shame, and the government has quite clearly chosen shame. In those circumstances, one has to wonder what Mr Howard genuinely means by being relaxed and comfortable. In my judgment, he means by that that there is no need for himâand he is quite relaxed about thisâto sack millionaire ministers. It also means that he is comfortable that those ministers can enjoy a rising share balance. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI would have to agree with Senator Carr about one thingâthat people are becoming cynical about what goes on in politics. Here we are back in parliament after being away for nearly two months, and lots of things have happened since 8 December last year. We have an economy that is going along very well, but we do not hear anything about that from the opposition.

speech.para: All we have heard from the opposition over the last two months is that they are all writing books on how the Labor Party should operate. Talk about conflict of interest! One would have to wonder what sort of interests a lot of members on the other side have with publishing companies. That is the only way they seem to be able to make any money.

As for this code of conduct business that has been going on today, I suppose we could trawl back over the history books and look at all those things that happened in the past with former members and ministers of the Labor Party. My colleagues have mentioned a lot of those today. We could talk about the perceived conflict of interest that the former Prime Minister had with the piggeries and all those sorts of things. I do not want to go into all of that. I do not want to come in here and make the obvious comment.

Talking about conflict of interest, when people are elected to this place, they have to declare their interests. Do the majority of the Labor Party on the other side declare their interests in the trade union movement, because 82 per cent of the ALP senators on the other side are associated with trade unions? Nineteen of the last 20 senators elected to this place are trade union members. Do they represent the people or do they represent the trade union movement? Where is the conflict of interest there?

The point I am trying to make is that, after the amount of time that we have been away from this place, I would have thought we would have had some sensible debate today about things that affect people in the communityâlike unemployment, law and order, and the high incidence of drugs. We have seen over the Christmas break much publicity about the drug situation in New South Wales. With an election coming up in New South Wales, I would have thought we might have heard something about what is happening there from both sides of politics. No. What do we have?

talk.start.para: âA broken record.

âWe have a broken record on a perceived conflict of interest because a minister has been open and clean and come forward and made the points about what he may or may not have done. He did that quite openly and, I believe, quite fairly. Yet here we go trying to denigrate another fine member of this side of politics.
âPlaying the man and not the ball.

âAbsolutely, it is playing the man and not the ball. I hope that we get some more sensible debate today and get back to what we are supposed to be doingâthat is, running the country, not running each other down.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: âIt is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death on Friday, 5 February 1999 of former Senator Neville Thomas Bonner AO, a senator for the state of Queensland from 1971 to 1983.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: âby leaveâI move:

speech.para: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death, on Friday, 5 February 1999, of Neville Thomas Bonner AO, a senator for the State of Queensland from 1971 to 1983, places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service and tenders its profound sympathy to his family in their bereavement.

Neville Bonner's life was one of extraordinary treatment. He was born in the most humble of circumstances. He was orphaned at the age of nine. During his earlier working life he worked as a dairy hand, stockman and carpenter. Ultimately, he entered the federal parliament when he was chosen to fill a casual vacancy in the Senate in 1971. He was then elected to the Senate a further three times and served as a Queensland senator until 1983.

As is well known, he was the first Australian Aboriginal to serve in the federal parliament. A Jagera elder, Neville had a lifelong commitment to recognition for Aboriginal people and was outspoken on Aboriginal rights. He served on many committees and in various offices of this Senate. After he left the Senate, he was named Australian of the Year for outstanding personal achievement and for efforts on behalf of the Aboriginal people. He was appointed an Officer in the General Division of the Order of Australia in 1984.

His remarkable life was well chronicled by his grandson Mitchell Kunde at his funeral service last Friday. As he expressed it better than I would be able to, I seek leave to incorporate a copy of that eulogy in the Senate Hansard. Leave granted.
The eulogy read as followsâ

A few months ago, I accompanied my grandfather on his last official engagement to the men's reconciliation committee dinner in Brisbane. Grandfather was presented with an award in honour of his outstanding contribution to the process of reconciliation. When he announced that to be his public swan song, all 550 men, without exception, rose to their feet and gave a deafening acclamation, many with tears in their eyes.

More recently, the state government honoured my grandfather by naming a large and impressive government building in William Street, Brisbane, `The Neville Bonner Building'. On Monday, in his honour, the flags flew at half mast on all state government buildings.

The outpouring of sorrow throughout the nation since his passing last Friday has been astounding. And here today are gathered Her Majesty's representatives, our Prime Minister and our State Premier, past and present state and federal parliamentarians, leaders of commerce, clergy of all denominations, elders of Aboriginal tribal `countries' from across this land, and those he loved and served so willinglyâthe people of the State of Queensland.
So who was this man who could walk with kings nor lose the common touch. . .

Neville Thomas Bonner was born on a government issue blanket under a loan palm tree on Ukerebagh Island at Tweed Heads, on 28 March, 1922. His mother was visiting from her Jagera country. He was the grandson of `Jung Jung', the last fully initiated member of the Jagera tribe, whose tribal `country' takes in the entire watershed of the Brisbane River. Neville Bonner, by right of inheritance was the elder of Jagera country.

His early life was that of a fringe-dweller, and he experienced hunger and cold, cruel racial discrimination, despair and a lack of schooling. When he was 11 years old, his mother died and he was taken into the care of his maternal grandmother. When he was 13, his grandmother took him to Beaudesert where he received his only formal schooling for one year. Neville Bonner was of necessity, self-taught. He was always a strong advocate of education for all young aborigines.

The following year Neville Bonner's grandmother died and the young Neville Bonner began working on a dairy farm. At age 15 he became his own man and he hit the road with a swag. Over the years he worked on banana plantations, ring-barking and scrub felling. He became an expert cane cutter and later worked as a rough-rider and stockman. Then he rose to a position as head stockman on various large cattle stations. This is where his attachment for his trademark R.M. Williams boots began.

In July 1943, he married the now late Mrs Mona Bonner.
