GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE REPORT BY THE SENATE ECONOMICS REFERENCES COMMITTEE PROMOTING AUSTRALIAN INDUSTRY: CREATING OPPORTUNITIES
1. OVERVIEW AND UPDATE OF THE GOVERNMENT'S INDUSTRY POLICY
Since the Senate Economics References Committee conducted its inquiry into Australia's industry policy, there have been a number of significant developments that have helped shape that policy.
In December 1997, the Government delivered Investing for Growth which contained a
$1.26 billion strategy to help revitalise the Australian economy, cut unemployment and build vibrant, internationally competitive industries.

In August 1998, the Government released its plan for taxation reformâA New Tax System. The Government also announced that it would consult with business on the business tax reform proposals released as part of the tax package.

During the 1998 Federal election campaign, the Government announced a range of initiatives in its Making Industry Stronger statement. Following its re-election, the Government announced a number of portfolio changes designed to deliver a more coherent and integrated approach to industry development.

In addition, the unfolding of the Asian economic crisis has highlighted the importance of sound macroeconomic policy, ongoing microeconomic reform and industry policies that let winners pick themselves. The Government's commitment to such policies has helped insulate Australia from the worst effects of the crisis.

The Government will continue to build on its approach to economic growth contained in Investing for Growth and remains committed to its goal of securing sustainable levels of higher economic growth for Australia. As such, the Government's approach is based on sound macroeconomic policy settings, continued microeconomic reform and business programs based on the key drivers of growthâinnovation, investment and exports.

Central to the Government's industry policy is its commitment to strengthening the competitive advantage of Australian industry by further enhancing the business operating environment and by pushing for better market access for our products.

The policy initiatives under the Government's election commitment, Making Industry Stronger, and the tax reform plan are designed to reduce business costs, attract investment and secure jobs, foster innovation, encourage the provision of capital to business for growth, develop industries of the future, and increase the international competitiveness of Australian industries.
Innovation
Innovation is crucial to achieving improved productivity, increased competitiveness, and sustainable economic and job growth.

The Government has a number of policies and programmes which provide support for innovation, create better links between public sector research and industry, and encourage technology diffusion through the economy. These initiatives include the direct funding of research institutions such as the CSIRO and Cooperative Research Centres and the provision of tax incentives to encourage businesses to undertake research and development.

Other initiatives to encourage innovation include increased support for the research and development Start Programme to provide industry with support for industrial research and development, from the early stages of innovation through to the development and commercialisation phases and on to production maturity. The Innovation Investment Fund has had its funding increased to further assist technology-based businesses access equity finance to fund the commercialisation of their research. The Government has also recently announced that it will foster a national system of innovation based on linkages between industry, research institutions and government.
Investment

The competition for international investment funds is acute, with many economies offering locational incentives which distort international investment flows. To help redress this, the Government has established Invest Australiaâan investment promotion, attraction and facilitation agency. It has also appointed a Strategic Investment Coordinator to facilitate investment in projects of major national significance and advise the Government on the need for investment incentives in limited and special circumstances.

The Government has also introduced several programmes to facilitate investment in key areasâsuch as the establishment of the Pharmaceutical Industry Investment Programme and the Automotive Competitiveness and Investment Scheme. Such programmes provide an environment that is conducive to long-term investment decisions and for developing internationally competitive industries.
Market Access

Australia has a small domestic economy in world terms and its industries need to participate in overseas markets to grow. However, no matter how competitive industry becomes, export success will not be achieved unless Australian goods and services have open and fair access to overseas markets. The Government is therefore pushing for freer and fairer trade so that Australian goods and services have better access to overseas markets and sees its memberships of the World Trade Organisation (WTO) and Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) as key opportunities to pursue this agenda. Australia is also pursuing the removal of trade and investment barriers through bilateral negotiations.
Structural Adjustment

Reductions in the levels of protection, combined with reforms to the economy, require industry to continue to adapt to a new business environment in order to prosper. The Government understands the need for some structural adjustment measures to help industry to restructure and to become world competitive while the level of protection is steadily reduced. Structural adjustment measures form an integral part of the Government's policies for key industry sectors and are aimed at facilitating the reform process while minimising transition costs.

An example of such assistance is the adjustment measures (ie the Automotive Competitiveness and Investment Scheme and Market Access Development Strategy) which accompanied the recent decision to maintain passenger motor vehicle tariffs at 15 per cent between the years 2000 and 2004, before reducing them to 10 per cent on 1 January 2005. The decision reflects the Government's desire to achieve balanced outcomes in the interests of the community as a whole and to provide predictability and certainty for industry, while maintaining Australia's commitment to its international obligations.
Other Key Initiatives

The Government has announced that it will strengthen the partnership between government and industry through the continued strategic application of Action Agendas in key industries. Action Agendas are formulated jointly by industry and government, and provide opportunities for industry representatives to communicate and consider best practice, tackle sectoral priorities and plan for the future. Action Agendas can also be used to clarify the balance of responsibilities between industry and government, enabling both parties to overcome impediments to growth. As Action Agendas are based on a whole-of-government approach, they allow for more effective coordination and integration of government policies that impact on the business sector. For instance, the broad ranging Action Agenda for the information industry is designed to foster the development of this key enabling industry.

The Government has also announced that it will encourage capital for growth through the introduction of a Venture Awareness programme and proposes changes to the Pooled Development Fund programme to increase patient equity capital for small and medium sized enterprises. In addition, to ensure that Australian industry is well placed to take advantage of the opportunities for growth that lie ahead, the Government will introduce Australian Industry 2010 which comprises three elements: (i) the Australian Industrial Structure Projectâa major study of Australian industrial structure which builds on the Action Agenda initiative; (ii) the Industry Outcomes and Outlook Statementâwhich will review the performance of key industry sectors, report on the effect of industry programmes and articulate the priorities for industry policy; and (iii) institute a new annual National Industry Outlook Conference to bring together academic, business and government analysts to promote ideas and debate on directions for Australia's manufacturing and service industries.

para.inline: 2. THE GOVERNMENT'S POSITION AND COMMENTS ON THE RECOMMENDATIONS OF THE REPORT

interjection.para: A fundamental problem facing Australia today is the continuing high level of unemployment, including structural and regional unemployment. For Australia to address this issue effectively requires us to adopt a successful high growth strategy, based on improving the productive performance of all Australian enterprises, especially those which export or compete against imports.
Agree

The aim of the Government's industry policy framework, announced in the Investing for Growth statement, is to deliver Australia an annual growth rate of more than 4 per cent on average over the decade to 2010.

This framework is helping to create a more competitive business environment for all Australia enterprisesâone characterised by low interest rates, stable prices, a more flexible and efficient labour market, competitively-priced infrastructure facilities and the identification and removal of market impediments and unnecessary government regulation. Future reforms to improve the competitiveness of the business environment include reform of the taxation system and increasing competition in areas like energy, transportation and telecommunications.

An integral part of this framework is initiatives to encourage innovation and investment, factors which are essential to upgrading technology and improving productivity and competitiveness. Other elements of the framework include initiatives to help Australian business to develop and expand their export markets (eg, the Export Access and TradeStart programmes will boost opportunities for regional and smaller exporters), make Australia a more attractive site for international manufacturing and warehousing and help specific industries restructure to meet the challenges of globalisation and increase their international competitiveness.

In addition, the Government is actively fostering the development of the information industries and business uptake of online technologies. These policies offer the prospect of increased productivity and access to innovation and new market opportunities for all industries across the economy.
Such a strategy should be based upon the Government developing a long term (5 to 10 years) industry policy framework with a clear definition of its economic and social objectives.
Agree

The Government's industry policy framework has a long term focus and clear objectives. In particular, its economic growth objective will over time generate higher employment growth which in turn will reduce unemployment and poverty.

At the same time, the Government's industry policy framework includes a mixture of long, medium and short-term initiatives. The longer term initiatives are aimed at providing a skilled labour force and predictability and certainty for industry to undertake long-term investment and restructuring to meet the challenges of globalisation. Such initiatives include the apprenticeship scheme, Automotive Competitiveness and Investment Scheme, R&D Start and Textile, Clothing and Footwear programmes and the establishment of Invest Australia. These are complemented by short and medium term initiatives which are required to allow flexibility to respond to rapid changes in circumstances such as those experienced in the information industries and the traded sector. Such initiatives include the Information Technology Online Programme, assistance provided by the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation and anti-dumping measures.

Moreover, the framework is based on a whole-of-government approach. Policies on industry development, trade facilitation, macroeconomic settings, microeconomic reform, investment attraction, innovation promotion, education and training, and business assistance programmes are integrated into a framework to foster a more internationally competitive Australia.

In summary, the Government recognises that there are impediments to the efficient operation of markets, such as the ability of Australian firms to fully capture the returns on their R&D investment. In addition, specific industries may need help in restructuring to meet the challenges of globalisation. As such, the Government has adopted a targeted approach to providing assistance to specific industries, intervening only in clear instances of market failure, and only where the benefits from intervention outweigh the costs.

Within the context of a consensual national policy framework, government should accept a role, within and across key industry sectors, where intervention is deemed appropriate. This may include government, in conjunction with industry, developing action agendas and formulating specific goals at industry sector level, under which both parties can clearly identify their obligations.
The Government supports the development of Action Agendas

The Government is building a durable partnership between industry and all levels of government through its programme of Action Agendas. Action Agendas are formulated jointly by industry and government, and provide opportunities for industry representatives to communicate and consider best practice, tackle sectoral priorities and plan for the future. Action Agendas can also be used to clarify the balance of responsibilities between industry and government, enabling both parties to overcome impediments to growth.
As Action Agendas are based on a whole-of-government approach, they allow for more effective coordination and integration of government policies that impact on the business sector.

Possible models could include the Wine 2025 plan, the Supermarket to Asia plan, the TCF and Auto industry plans and the forthcoming plans of the Information and Tourism Industries. Particular focus should be given to industries that provide the greatest potential for growth in high skilled jobs and in employment opportunities.
Agree

The Government's model for Action Agendas is not prescriptive. It is important that each Agenda is developed in a flexible way that is appropriate to the needs and characteristics of the particular industry sector. In general, Action Agendas comprise the following elements: analysis of current industry performance; identification of impediments to growth; and development of priorities for reform.

The primary focus of Action Agendas is to lift the growth prospects of important industry sectors. Action Agendas have already been implemented for agrifood, information industries, automotive and tourism and are being developed for chemicals, building and construction, textiles clothing and footwear, liquefied natural gas, downstream petroleum products, renewable energy and digital broadcasting. In addition, action agendas have recently been announced for furniture, biotechnology, sport and recreation, heavy engineering and infrastructure, and printing.

The key objectives of such a national approach to industry development must be to improve the ability of firms in Australia to compete in the domestic and global marketplace, as well as providing Australians with high skilled, secure jobs and employment opportunities. To achieve these objectives Australia must become an attractive investment location where:

(a) the operation of Australia's Venture Capital Industry must be kept under constant review, and new initiatives taken to continually expand our Venture Capital Market. In that context, an evaluation of the small business Innovation Investment Fund (IIF) should be undertaken prior to the May 2000 Budget in order to evaluate its effectiveness and to allow any new initiatives to be implemented at that time.

(b) a major element in our ability to foster growth opportunities among Australian business will be our capacity to attract investment funds that are focused on the longer term as opposed to short term profit taking investments. Therefore, Australia needs to adopt policies, including a capital gains tax regime, that are distinctly biased towards long term investment.

(c) Attracting investment should be a key element of any tax reform package. The Committee considers that any comprehensive review of the taxation system should include a focus on its ability to attract investment as well as its broader impact on business (ie, Capital Gains Tax could be applied on a sliding scale, reducing over a set time period; arrangements for Limited Partnerships could be reintroduced to encourage investment from offshore). The system should not unfairly penalise business and deter innovation.
Agree-in-part

The Government agrees that the operation of Australia's Venture Capital Industry must be kept under constant review to see if new initiatives need to be taken to expand our Venture Capital Market. There is limited value in conducting an evaluation of the IIF, a ten-year programme, within two years of it becoming operational. The programme will be evaluated in 2001-02 when the effectiveness of the programme in achieving its objectives is more likely to be apparent.

The Government will consider options for the reform of business taxation, including capital gains tax, in its Business Income Tax Review. The Review will make recommendations on the fundamental design of the business tax system, the processes of ongoing policy making, drafting of legislation and the administration of business taxation.

The recommendations will be consistent with the aims of improving the competitiveness and efficiency of Australian business, providing a secure source of revenue, enhancing the stability of taxation arrangements, improving simplicity and transparency and reducing the costs of compliance. The Review will adopt a comprehensive approach to reform driven by clear, sound principles involving a move towards greater commercial reality.

There will be consultation with business on the proposed reforms. The process of consultation will include an assessment of the design and the administration of the tax regimes affecting business to identify their main shortcomings and their impediments to productive activity and innovation.

In considering the future development of Australian industry, the focus should be on industries which add substantial Australian value to products and services; have a high degree of income and market elasticity of demand; have the capacity to provide substantial employment in medium/highly skilled occupations; and where industry programmes are established they should have to meet clearly established goals. In working toward those goals the results must be regularly reviewed and benchmarked against agreed and soundly based performance criteria, including job creation goals and other commitments entered into by both government and industry.
Agree-in-part

A major focus of the Government's industry policy framework is to facilitate the growth of high value added, high wage industries by creating an internationally competitive environment for all Australian industries. The aim is to provide the conditions for higher levels of long-term investment and innovation, leading to higher economic and employment growth. To help support this objective, the Government has instituted a programme of Action Agendas to lift the growth prospects of important industry sectors, including high value-adding industries. An example of this is the Government's approach to fostering the development of the information industries. The Government recognises the role of information technology as an enabling technology and has established an Action Agenda to facilitate the more rapid development of a domestic industry base in software, information technology services and manufacturing.

That said, too much emphasis on developing high value added goods and services at the expense of lower value added ones where Australia may have a competitive advantage, could detract from wealth creation and employment growth. Also, the promotion of goods and services that have a high degree of income and market elasticity of demand should not be at the expense of niche high value added products often characterised by strong brand identification and relatively stable market demand (eg, high quality wines).

With respect to business programmes, the Government's objective is to ensure that they are delivered efficiently and achieve effective outcomes. Current policy requires that all programmes have clear objectives and measurable performance indicators that focus on end

results; should avoid duplication with other programmes; should be of a scale and duration that are consistent with the market impediments being addressed; must have clear eligibility and entitlement criteria; and should have risk management strategies that match the size of the risk and potential for fraud. Business programmes are regularly reviewed as a matter of course and outcomes benchmarked against performance criteria where appropriate.

Promotion of Australian industrial products be given a high priority. This could be achieved by diversification of promotion targets and export markets and by identification of growth markets for Australian products. The Export Facilitation Scheme should be retained in a form acceptable to the World Trade Organisation (WTO), with consideration to be given to improved flexibility, eligibility and limits. Duplication in the regulations applied to industry at the various levels of government should be eliminated. A central source of information should be established which will give Australian industry access to current information about the policies of Australia's trading partners which could affect the export potential of Australian products.
Agree-in-part
The promotion of Australia as a source of competitive goods and services in the international market is viewed by the Government as vital.
Trade related promotional initiatives undertaken by the Government include:
. the establishment of the Market Development Task Force to facilitate wider market access and export promotion and to address market access barriers;

. the implementation of a National Trade Fairs Strategy which harnesses the efforts of the Commonwealth and States to help Australian firms gain maximum impact from their participation in trade fairs;

. the extension of the Export Market Development Grants scheme which provides assistance to Australian companies to seek out and develop overseas markets through the partial reimbursement of promotional and marketing expenditure;

. the establishment of TradeStart, a programme to improve export outcomes for regional Australia which will draw on the resources of the private sector and links with State government bodies to ensure that Australian businesses outside the major metropolitan centres have improved access to export assistance; and

. the extension of funding for the Export Access programme which assists small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to undertake export activity on a sustainable basis, and its expansion to increase its focus on rural and regional exporters.

To facilitate the growth of an export culture in Australia, the Government has integrated the Duty Drawback and Tariff Export Concession schemes with TRADEX, which will provide relief from customs and excise duty and sales tax on imported goods intended for re-export or used as inputs to exports. And the Manufacture in Bond scheme will allow firms to use Australia as a base for hub operations servicing the Asia Pacific region without incurring duty liability
on goods intended for re-export or used as inputs to exports.

The Export Facilitation Scheme is to be replaced by the, WTO consistent, Automotive Competitiveness and Investment Scheme. The Government will also introduce the Automotive Market Access and Development Strategy. The aim of these initiatives is to provide certainty for new investment in the automotive industry while enabling Australia to meet its international obligations.

The Government has also encouraged the development of national regulation review programmes for industry sectors (eg, the Blair Review of Food Regulations) which has facilitated the identification of duplicative regulation and the recommendation of a coordinated response across jurisdictions. In addition, sectoral projects have been undertaken (in industry sectors such as aquaculture) to streamline regulations across all levels of government and to develop integrated and efficient processes for regulatory approval.

Mechanisms are already in place to enhance government-business communications and consultation on trade-related issues (including, at the national level, through mechanisms such as the Trade Policy Advisory Council, consultation with Australian members of the APEC Business Advisory Council and APEC Business Forum, National Trade Consultations and the Agricultural Trade Consultative Group). In addition, the Government:
. has initiated specialist market access teams to help the food, information, textile, clothing and footwear and automotive industries;
. has appointed a Special Envoy for the Automotive Sector, with extensive industry contacts and the capacity to generate strong government/industry collaboration on automotive matters;
. has established sectoral market facilitation teams based in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, which are working with industry in developing market access and trade strategies;

. has held a series of roundtables in major regional centres around Australia involving the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Trade and selected SMEs to discuss trade and liberalisation issues;
. is consulting closely with Australian industry in formulating Australia's position on APEC's process of early voluntary sectoral liberalisation; and
. is holding extensive consultations with business on developments in East Asian economies, particularly in assessing the impact on various industries.

With regard to a central source of information, Austrade has established the Export Hotline as the main entry point to Austrade for the price of a local telephone call from anywhere in Australia. The Hotline provides readily available information and internal and external referrals. Austrade also operates an easily accessible website which provides information about Australia's trading partners.

An independent body should be established at arms length from the Government (but reporting directly to Government) for the purposes of advising on and evaluating the effectiveness of the national industry policy framework in achieving its economic and social objectives. Such a body, in evaluating the effectiveness of the national approach would be required to examine and advise on alternative policy options which may be desirable and which could lead to more effective outcomes.
Disagree

The Government has already established the Productivity Commission which advises on all aspects of microeconomic reform, including industry policy. The Commission's work covers all sectors of the economy. It extends to the public and private sectors and focuses on areas of Commonwealth as well as State and Territory responsibility. The statutory functions of the Commission are to:
. conduct independent public enquires into matters relating to industry, industry development and productivity;
. undertake economic research about matters relating to industry, industry development and productivity;
. provide advice on request from the Treasurer into matters relating to industry, industry development and productivity;
. promote public understanding into matters relating to industry, industry development and productivity;

. receive and investigate complaints about the implementation of competitive neutrality arrangements in relation to Commonwealth government business and business activities through the Competitive Neutrality Complaints Office;
. provide secretariat services to government bodies, including monitoring the performance of Government Trading Enterprises and Government Service Providers; and
. provide advice to government about regulatory issues through the Office of Regulation Review.

The Government also receives input from industry advisory councils such as the National Building and Construction Council and the Automotive Trade Council. The Government has also announced that an annual National Industry Outlook Conference will be held to bring together academic, business and governmental analysts to promote ideas and debate on directions for Australia's manufacturing and service industries.

The adoption of a consensus approach to industry development, which clearly defines national goals and objectives, would provide a solid foundation for long-term planning by individual companies and a stable policy environment, within which long-term investment decisions can be made.
Agree-in-principle

The Government recognises the importance to industry of consistency in policy formulation and application in regard to industry development. It is for this reason that the Government regularly liaises with other levels of government through the Council of Australian Governments (COAG) on matters of national importance or where clarification of roles between governments is required. COAG functions include:
. increasing cooperation among governments in the national interest;
. cooperation to achieve an integrated national market; and
. consultation on major issues of an inter-governmental nature.

In addition, government programmes such as TradeStart routinely make use of Commonwealth and State programme delivery agencies or mechanisms and require a high degree of inter-government coordination and cooperation.

The Government has also introduced a system of Action Agendas through which, in partnership with industry, the development of specific sectors is addressed. Action Agendas are built on a partnership between business and government, but are also based on a whole-of-government approach, allow ing for more effective coordination and integration of government policies as they impact on the business sector.

To build on the progress that is being made through Action Agendas, the Government has announced an Australian Industrial Structure Project which will seek to analyse the influence of globalisation and technological change on Australia's industrial structure over the period to 2010 and beyond. The National Industry Outlook Conference will also contribute towards fostering a consensus approach to industry development.

The Committee believes that a significant feature that defines successful companies in both the domestic and global markets is the quality of management and managerial processes. The Government needs to ensure that effective resources are targeted at the development of human capital, with particular emphasis on managerial capabilities.
Agree

The Government is committed to strengthening the competitive advantage of Australian industry through initiatives to upgrade and update workforce skills to meet the challenges of globalisation. These initiatives include:
. the Enterprise Education Strategy and the Innovation Culture programme, both designed to foster an enterprise culture;
. the Enterprise Development Programme which delivers a range of enterprise improvement services;
. the AusIndustry Environmental Management Programme which includes energy management and environmental accounting modules;
. Quality Management for Business programme which has a focus on SME needs;
. Strategic Planning for Business; and
. a mentoring trial to assist businesses to engage a mentor.

In addition, the Government plans to initiate a new Venture Awareness programme to assist investor funds to understand the potential of venture capital. The programme will establish a set of investment benchmarks for Australian venture capital to help Australian investment funds improve their evaluation of venture capital investments and better inform Australian investors of opportunities in venture capital.

Consideration to be given to the establishment of a process to oversee government procurement and outsourcing practices in key industries, which can lay the basis for developing industries to compete in the global economy. Due consideration should be given to the effect of those practices on local industries (particularly in regional Australia) to ensure that the local industries are not disadvantaged. To the extent permitted by the WTO, and consistent with cost effectiveness, the government should use procurement and outsourcing policy as a tool of industry policy.
Agree

Government policy, as articulated in the Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines: Core Policies and Principles requires agencies to seek value for money in procuring goods and services for the Commonwealth so buyers can choose the most cost-effective outcome. Value for money is the essential test against which agencies must justify any procurement outcome. It is not an attribute or criterion in itself but is a basis for comparing alternative solutions. Notwithstanding this, to the extent possible under Australia's international obligations, and consistent with cost effectiveness, the Government will continue to use government procurement and outsourcing policy to support industry objectives.

The Government requires Commonwealth officials involved in procurement to have regard to its requirement to support industrial development through their procurement activity, as outlined in the Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines: Core Policy and Principles. The Government will continue to assist industry development through procurement activities such as, leveraging government purchasing through the Partnerships for Development, Fixed Term Arrangement and Endorsed Supplier Arrangement programmes. For instance, the Telecommunications Carrier Industry Development Plan has been an important element of information industries development policies. In addition, the outsourcing of the Government's information technology infrastructure needs, as announced in the 1997 Budget, has provided significant opportunities for the development of Australia's information technology industry. By requiring strict contractual industry development commitments, the size of the Government's purchasing power has acted as a catalyst to attract international activities and operations to Australia. There is also a strong preference for high value added Australian products and services and maximising participation in information technology outsourcing by Australian SMEs. This has assisted SMEs to develop skills and relationships which have helped them develop an international focus, gain access to international markets and build internationally competitive capabilities.

It should be noted that Australia is not a signatory to the WTO Agreement on Government Procurement and therefore, procurement policies and practices are not subject to the agreement. However, Australia does have international government procurement obligations relating to its membership of APEC and the WTO General Agreement on Trade in Services (GATS). Although GATS coverage does not currently extend to government procurement of services, the WTO is currently looking at extending GATS coverage to government procurement, which may result in international obligations for Australia in this area.
Under the Australia New Zealand Government Procurement Agreement (ANZGPA), New Zealand products and suppliers are accorded the same treatment as Australian products and services.
The Committee urges rapid legislative implementation of the Government's decision to adopt the recommendations of the Willett report on anti-dumping and countervailing duties.
Agree
The Government has introduced a new anti-dumping and countervailing system in response to the Willett report. This came into effect on 24 July 1998. Under the new arrangements:

. the time taken to investigate and complete an anti-dumping inquiry has been reduced from up to 220 days to 155 days at which point the Minister is able to apply duties. In addition, provisional measures can apply from 60 days after an investigation has commenced. The faster investigation process remains consistent with Australia's obligations under its agreements with the WTO;
. industry has increased opportunity to respond to a statement of essential facts. This statement will be published by day 110 of the investigation, with interested parties having 20 days to respond;

. duplication of investigations has been removed, with the abolition of the Anti-Dumping Authority (ADA). Formerly there were two separate investigationsâthe ADA and the Australian Customs Service. These have been replaced by one investigation process undertaken by Customs; and

. greater transparency of the investigation process will be achieved through an independent appeal mechanism administered by the Trade Measures Review Officer within the Department of Industry, Science and Resources. This officer will be able to review the Customs investigation but not institute a further investigation.

A major factor in the ability of firms to compete in the domestic and global market place is their ability to be innovative in all aspects of the business, including production methods, new products, marketing and provision of services. Therefore, the promotion of research and development must be a key priority for government. Government initiatives in this area should include:

(a) policies that maximise expenditure on research and development not only by government but by individual companies and institutions. This may require linking the level of government support for research and development to the level of commitment to research and development expenditure by individual companies.
i. establishing or maintaining appropriate tax concessions for expenditure on industrial research and development;
ii. introducing policies which maximise the opportunities for, and the likelihood of, the commercialisation in Australia of the outcomes of government-supported research and development;
iii. the formulation of industry/research consortia; and
iv. continuation of technology transfer programmes, such as the Partnerships for Development Programme.
The Committee notes that the Government has acted to remove the duty differential between imported computer components and pre-assembled.
Agree-in-principle

The Government has identified innovation as one of the key drivers of growth and agrees that it is a major factor in enabling industry to be competitive. The Government provides substantial support for science, innovation and R&D. Support is estimated to be about $3.7 billion in 1998-99, a real increase of 0.4 per cent over the previous year.

This recommendation is in accord with current Government policy. A range of market-driven programmes is in place to encourage R&D in industry and institutions. For example, the R&D Tax Concession and R&D Start. A strong commitment to R&D by industry is required to achieve the objectives of these programmes. For example, the R&D Tax Concession benefit is claimed through the taxation system, after R&D expenditure is incurred, and the benefits received are in direct proportion to the amount expended. R&D Grants provide a maximum subsidisation of 50 per cent, with the remainder of funds committed by firms or their collaborators.
b)
i. The Government has confirmed its support of an R&D tax concession in the December 1997 Industry Statement Investing for Growth.
ii. The new Innovation Investment Fund programme is designed to increase the flow of venture capital for the commercialisation of new technology in small high-technology businesses.

iii. There are substantial opportunities for the formation of research and industry consortia under current policies, including the Cooperative Research Centres programme, and the R&D Tax Concession and the R&D Start programmes.

iv. Investing for Growth announced the enhancement of technology transfer programmes with a commitment of $108 million over four years for the Technology Diffusion Programme. The programme has three related components which target international technology collaboration, industry access to leading edge technology and industry uptake of electronic commerce.

As noted by the Committee, the Government announced in the 1998 Budget the removal of tariffs on imported computer components (effective 1 July 1998). This decision corrects an anomaly whereby fully assembled information technology equipment was imported duty free but inputs to the manufacture of those same goods in Australia attracted a duty. The decision lowers the cost of manufacturing in Australia and improves the international competitiveness of Australian industry.

GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE REPORT ON THE PORTRAYAL OF VIOLENCE IN THE ELECTRONIC MEDIA BY THE SENATE SELECT COMMITTEE ON THE COMMUNITY STANDARDS RELEVANT TO THE SUPPLY OF SERVICES UTILISING ELECTRONIC TECHNOLOGIES.

On 9 July 1996, the government announced its decisions on the recommendations of the Committee of Ministers on the Portrayal of Violence in the electronic media (the Ministerial committee), which had been established in the wake of the Port Arthur massacre. Over 700 submissions and letters were received by the Ministerial committee which had to report to Cabinet within a short time-frame. The government decided to adopt the Ministerial committee's recommendation to refer matters arising from the public submissions to the Senate Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Electronic Technologies (the Select Committee) for further consideration. This recommendation was intended to ensure that the government was fully apprised of community expectations, and to enable all submitters to have an adequate opportunity to be heard.

On 22 August 1996, the Senate referred these matters to the Select Committee. The Select committee tabled its Report on the Portrayal of Violence in the Electronic Media on 13 February 1997 (the Report).

The Department of Communications, Information Technology and the Arts sought comments from all organisations affected by the recommendations in the Report: the Australian Broadcasting Authority (ABA), the Office of Film and Literature Classification (OFLC), the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations (FACTS), the ABC, the SBS, the Australian Film, Television and Radio School (AFTRS), the Federation of Australian Narrowcasting and Subscription Services (FANSS), the Confederation of Australian Subscription Television (CAST), Young Media Australia (YMA), Australian Record Industry Association (ARIA), and the Commonwealth Department of Education, Training and Youth Affairs. The Department also received comments from the Child Health Council of South Australia. These contributions have been taken into account in the government's response to the Report.

During the 1998 Federal election, the government made a commitment to direct the ABA to decide whether viewers would be better served by a uniform code of practice across the free-to-air industry. The government expects to implement this commitment in the near future and anticipates that the ABA will have regard to relevant recommendations of the Select committee and the government's response.

para.inline: The committee recommends that organisations such as Young Media Australia, the Australian Broadcasting Authority and the Australian Film and Television School be given a financial allocation to run seminars for script writers and film and video games producers aimed at highlighting the need for a more balanced and realistic portrayal of the long term effects of violence.

interjection.para: The government supports the recommendation in principle and considers that industry should also bear some responsibility for the training of its professionals. In this regard, the government noted the interest expressed by those organisations mentioned in the recommendation to conduct such training. The production industry and the ABA might wish to consider the development of industry codes of practice to address this issue.

para.inline: The committee recommends that the ABA undertake, at different times and for different periods, a review of television stations practice in the area of program promotion between the hours of 3.30pm and 8.30pm against their written codes to assess the extent of compliance (or otherwise) with their Codes of Practice.

interjection.para: Under the provisions of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992 (BSA), the ABA has a clear obligation to monitor compliance with codes of practice. The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has written to the ABA and the relevant radio and television industry bodies responsible for codes of practice expressing his concern about the content of broadcast programs. The government is confident that the ABA will continue to address community concerns about program content, consistent with the government's commitment to ensuring that broadcasters comply with codes of practice, and to the protection of children from unsuitable material. The government also notes that FACTS has addressed the appropriate scheduling of program promotions in its draft revised code of practice.

para.inline: (a) a telephone/fax Hotline be re-introduced by the ABA for the public to register complaints about television programs. The Hotline could work in a similar way to the one operated by the former ABT.
(b) that the ABA report on the operation of the Hotline in its annual report.

interjection.para: The Select committee has identified a degree of public concern about the effectiveness of the operation of the complaints system under the BSA and industry codes of practice. This concern appears to arise from the requirement to lodge complaints about code breaches with the broadcaster in the first instance, and the experience that some broadcasters do not provide a satisfactory response to those complaints.

The complaints process is designed to ensure that broadcasters, by being the first point of contact for alleged code breaches, are directly accountable to the public, and that they are aware of and respond directly to community concerns. The ABA will investigate any failure by a broadcaster to provide a satisfactory response to a complaint and take action if a breach has occurred. The government notes that the ABA already operates an 1800 number, and is required by the BSA to respond directly to complaints alleging breaches of the BSA or standards.

In June 1998, the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations (FACTS) agreed to consider a national phone number for program-related complaints. FACTS has now agreed to implement this proposal by providing a national information line accessible for the price of a local call from anywhere in Australia.
This national information line will provide callers with:
. Summary information on the commercial television industry Code of Practice and how to obtain a copy;
. Information on how to make a complaint; and
. The telephone numbers of commercial television stations (for making complaints).
FACTS has also agreed that the commercial television stations will run an advertising slot on average of once a day about the FACTS Code of Practice.

It has also indicated that the commercial television stations are willing to include the contact details of relevant individual television stations when they mail out copies of the Code of Practice to members of the public who request them.

FACTS has also agreed that, in future, individual television stations will take complaints about both programming and advertising matters, whereas previously complaints about advertising matters had to be made directly to the Advertising Standards Board (ASB). Where appropriate complaints will be referred on to the ASB for investigation.
These undertakings represent a significant enhancement of current arrangements for informing viewers about the relevant complaint mechanisms.
The Minister will ask the ABA to monitor these new arrangements and to report periodically on the extent to which they have raised the public's awareness of the relevant complaint mechanisms.

para.inline: (a) The committee recommends that the BSA 1992 be amended to allow the ABA to impose penalties, including "on the spot " fines of up to $100,000.00 on television stations on proven breaches of their own codes of practice.
(b) A decision on whether non-compliance had occurred would be required to be made within a 48-hour period.

interjection.para: The government remains committed to an effective system of co-regulation supported by appropriate community safeguards. As indicated in its response to the Select committee's Report on Operation of Codes of Practice in the Television Industry Part 1, the government is aware that there is a concern that there be appropriate sanctions available to deal with breaches of codes of practice. The BSA provides a range of sanctions that can be applied by the ABA, subject to the statutory requirement that it use its powers in aa manner commensurate with the seriousness of the breach'. This is a matter for the ABA's judgement, informed by its assessment of contemporary community standards.

The government will encourage broadcasters to give serious consideration to alternative approaches to addressing community concerns. These might include: providing a mechanism to direct an apology or retraction for minor code infringements; the requirement for broadcasters to retain records and complaints for longer periods; and the reduction of the time period which broadcasters currently have to respond to complaints under the codes of practice. In this regard, the ABA has commented that it believed there were benefits in formalising the role of swift `on air' corrections and apologies as soon after a specific episode as possible. The government will consider, in the light of industry responses, whether any changes consistent with the co-regulatory framework are required to supplement existing sanctions and strengthen the effectiveness of the system.

para.inline: The committee recommends that the ABA be made responsible for the classification of all children's programs (including cartoons for children).

interjection.para: One of the objects of the BSA is `to ensure that providers of broadcasting services place a high priority on the protection of children from exposure to program material which may be harmful to them'(s.3(j)). This object is given effect through industry codes of practice and, more particularly, through the ABA's Children's Television Standards, (CTS) determined under s.122 of the Act.

Under present arrangements, only programs to be broadcast by commercial television broadcasters specifically in fulfilment of the CTS (with which compliance by licensees is mandatory), are submitted to the ABA for classification. Responsibility for classifying the balance of programming, including other programs for children, rests with the broadcasters, consistent with the co-regulatory scheme of the BSA.

The government would be reluctant to remove the responsibility for classifying children's programs generally from broadcasters to the regulator, as it is a key element of the co-regulatory scheme that broadcasters be responsive and directly accountable to their audiences for their programming decisions.

The government is confident that there are adequate mechanisms in place to safeguard the interests of children in respect of programming not covered by pre-classification requirements of the CTS. These include the ABA's powers to require compliance with industry codes, and to widen the scope of matters covered by mandatory standards if the codes fail to provide appropriate safeguards. The ABA is also empowered to conduct or commission research to inform its regulatory responses to public concerns about children's programs. The government therefore does not support the recommendation.

para.inline: The committee recommends that the current on-air information campaign by the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations (FACTS) be modified so that, in addition to telling viewers that classification and consumer advice is available, information should be given about the meaning of each classification symbol.

interjection.para: The government reaffirms its response to the Select committee's Report on Operation of Codes of Practice in the Television Industry Part 1 that it considers action by broadcasters to regularly inform their audiences about the operation of codes of practice and related complaints processes is an important part of the co-regulatory system. The government notes that FACTS' revised draft code provides for 360 on air information spots per year. The current code provides a general obligation to provide on-air information about the availability of the code and also the complaints procedures.

The government therefore considers that the intent of this recommendation has been met by FACTS, but strongly urges the industry to continue to examine ways of ensuring audiences receive adequate information to make informed viewing choices.

para.inline: The committee recommends that separate guidelines be introduced for the classification of videotapes to ensure that higher standards are applied to videotapes than for the equivalent categories of film for cinema release.

interjection.para: As previously advised (refer Senate Hansard of 2 July 1998 page 4080) in relation to an identical recommendation contained in the Report on R-rated Material on Pay TV Part 2 and the Review of the Guidelines for the Classification of Film and Videotapes which was tabled in the Senate on 17 October 1996, the government does not support this recommendation.

The government's Law and Justice policy for the March 2 1996 election stated that it would ". . . .work with States and Territories in pursuit of clear standards for film, television, literature, computer and video games, audiotext and bulletin boards that operate to prevent the excessive portrayal of violence or obscenity."
Current policy sets the film and video criteria at identical thresholds.

Research reveals that there is clear support for the idea of having a similar classification scheme operating for television, film and video (79%). There are persuasive arguments that the system should continue in its present form to promote community understanding of, and confidence in, the classification process and to provide business certainty on a national basis.

The situation already exists where a free-to-air TV M, a film and video M and a computer game M may differ. Considerable consumer confusion is likely to follow if further differences are introduced, for example, a difference in content between a video M and a cinema M. This is particularly so as the content is invariably the same and the video version is usually released shortly after the end of the cinema season.

The Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Act 1995 also makes provision for consumer advice giving information about the content of films and videos. This enables adults and, in particular parents, to make informed choices about what they view and allow their children to view.

The hire or purchase of a video involves a conscious choice by a person. In relation to denying access by children to unsuitable material so obtained, this is a matter which falls directly into the area of parental responsibility. There are definite limits to what governments can do or be expected to do in controlling what occurs in individual homes.

The fact that some parents may act in what some may consider to be an irresponsible manner in this area is not an adequate excuse for curtailing the availability of material to adults generally (which could be the case if `R' rated material is to be classified at a higher threshold for videos) or parents who do act responsibly.

para.inline: (a) that the ABA, in association with the OFLC undertake at different times throughout the year a random audit of films classified for television by the television stations themselves and require the television stations to state:
(i) how much footage they have cut in the process of modifying the film for TV broadcast
(ii) their reasons for the classification they chose to give to the film under review, and
(b) that the ABA report on its findings in its annual report

interjection.para: The government considers that under the existing co-regulatory arrangements the classification of programs is a matter for broadcasters to implement through their codes of practice having regard to the classification requirements of section 123 of the BSA. The BSA obliges the ABA to monitor compliance with codes of practice, and to periodically review the operation of those provisions of the act that relate to program classification. The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has written to the ABA and the relevant radio and television industry bodies responsible for codes of practice expressing his concern about the content of broadcast programs. The government is confident that the ABA will exercise its existing powers to ensure that classifications reflect prevailing community standards.

para.inline: The committee recommends that television stations vary the use of the symbol V to indicate the level of violence in a film ranging from V low level violence to VV-medium level violence and VVV- to indicate high level violence.

interjection.para: The government notes FACTS' intention to include in its code a new AV classification. The revised Code states: "Material classified "AV" is suitable for viewing only by persons aged 15 years or over. It is unsuitable for "MA" classification because of the intensity and/or frequency of violence, or because violence is central to the theme. In other respects, the classification's requirements are identical to the "MA" classification." The AV classification will be accompanied by both spoken and written consumer advice concerning the level of elements such as language, violence, sex and nudity or drugs contained in the program. The FACTS code already requires brief consumer advice giving the principal elements which have contributed to the classification and indicating their intensity and/or frequency for M classified feature films and all MA classified programs. This requirement will be expanded under the revised code so that stations will have to provide such advice before all M and MA programs. Consumer advice will also be supplied with any other programs `which contains material of a strength or intensity which licensees reasonably believe viewers may not expect'. The government considers the intent of this recommendation has been met, but strongly urges the industry to continue to examine ways of ensuring audiences receive adequate information to make informed viewing choices.

para.inline: The committee recommends that the Attorney General increase the level of fees imposed by the OFLC for classification if the material classified is found to contain high level violence.

interjection.para: The government is of the view that concerns about material containing high level violence have been adequately addressed by the removal of such material from public exhibition, sale or hire.
Accordingly, the government does not support this recommendation.

para.inline: The committee recommends that the funds raised by increased fees be used to finance public education campaigns aimed at highlighting the possible adverse effects of watching large amounts of violent material.

interjection.para: In light of the matters set out in response to recommendation 10, the government does not support this recommendation.

para.inline: The committee recommends also that State and Territory Ministers consider proposals to require that all R-rated violent videos carry a label indicating that the content of such videos might be harmful to the mental wellbeing of children and those adults suffering from depression and other mental disorders.

interjection.para: The government does not support this recommendation.

The Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Act 1995 provides that the Classification Board must determine consumer advice giving information about the content of all films and videos which receive an `R" classification. Such consumer advice enables adults, including parents, to make informed choices about what they view and allow their children to view.

Existing labelling requirements are for the classification symbol, description and consumer advice to be displayed on the video cassette, the video cover (both on the spine and on the front cover) as well as at the introduction to the video itself. An example of the required labelling required is:
R 18+ RESTRICTED TO ADULTS
18 YEARS AND OVER.
MEDIUM LEVEL COARSE LANGUAGE
MEDIUM LEVEL VIOLENCE
To introduce further labelling could also detract from the classification labelling which shows the classification, age restriction, and consumer advice.

The impact of viewing violent material on a person's mental well-being is complex and the subject of considerable debate. The findings of such authoritative research studies as those conducted by the National Committee on Violence and the Australian Institute of Criminology do not provide conclusive evidence of a causal relationship between viewing violent material and the commission of crime.

The equivocal results are placed in perspective when other causative factors are taken into account. It is apparent that violence in the home, personality traits, substance abuse, mental illness and a variety of cultural and biological factors combine with media influences as possible precursors to violent behaviour. The government notes that some research findings indicate that people who have a propensity for violence tend to watch violent material. It is unlikely that such people will alter their viewing habits following the placement of warning labels on material they would normally choose to view. It is considered that the deleterious effects of depression and mental illness may be more effectively addressed through community health programs.

In relation to the recommendation that `R' rated violent videos be labelled as being potentially "harmful to the mental well-being of children", it should be noted that such videos are not legally available to persons under the age of 18 years. The committee's comment on page 34 of its report that "it appears relatively easy for children to obtain through rental outlets videos that cause concern to parents" is noted. It is considered, however, that this issue is better addressed through, for example, more effective education, point of sale controls and enforcement.
The enforcement of classification decisions and point of sale controls is the responsibility of the States and Territories.

In recognition of the importance of improving compliance with classification laws, the Commonwealth government has reached an agreement with all States and Territories to extend the Community Liaison Officer (CLO) scheme for a 3 year period following completion of the 62 week trial period. The role of the CLO is primarily educative. The CLO liaises with retailers, distributors, police and community groups in the participating jurisdictions to advise on the national classification scheme, the legal responsibilities of retailers and distributors and associated penalties for breaches of State and Territory classification enforcement acts.

para.inline: The committee recommends that when reporting news items which are identified by the television stations themselves as being accompanied by `'disturbing footage", that footage should only be shown in later evening news bulletin and not during the early evening news bulletin when large numbers of children are watching television.

interjection.para: The government acknowledges the Select committee's concerns about disturbing footage on the early evening news. The government notes that FACTS proposes to amend its code to ensure greater care and sensitivity in news and current affairs. There are three significant new clauses restricting the use of footage of dead and wounded, prohibiting unfair identification of individual people or companies in items about the behaviour of a group of persons or businesses; and requiring care in not identifying murder or accident victims before relatives are notified by authorities. A clause on the reporting of suicide has also been expanded for greater clarity. The government strongly urges the broadcasters to be vigilant in meeting the requirements of their codes of practice.

para.inline: The committee recommends that the ARIA Code of Practice Guidelines No. 3 for "material which are not permitted to be sold" be amended to add the word "suicide" after the words "incest" and "child abuse".

interjection.para: The government believes the promotion of suicide is unacceptable, and acknowledges that the sale of audio recordings containing lyrics which explicitly and gratuitously deal with and promote, incite or instruct in suicide is a matter of significant concern in the community. The government supports this recommendation and notes that the ARIA Code of Practice for Labelling with Explicit and Potentially Offensive Lyrics contains the guideline that albums containing lyrics which specifically instruct to commit suicide shall be refused classification as 18+, and are not permitted to be sold.

para.inline: The committee recommends that State and Territory education ministers take steps to encourage schools to offer a compulsory course on a critical evaluation of the media at some stage during the latter primary years.

interjection.para: The government notes that school education is the constitutional responsibility of the States and Territories, although it does have a strategic role in setting national directions and priorities. The government will bring this recommendation to the attention of State and Territory Education Ministers.

para.inline: The committee recommends that the Federal Government fund a public education campaign through the media to make parents and teachers aware of the means (such as the classification symbols, the V-chip as it becomes available and PICS labelling on the Internet) available to them to control material that their children watch and play with. The campaign should include information on how to find out more about how these control systems operate.

interjection.para: The government notes that the FACTS code requires commercial broadcasters to provide on air information about the codes. The government is considering how best to implement its decision to introduce the V-chip technology into all new television sets and will consider public education issues as part of its implementation strategy.

At the direction of the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts under s.171 of the BSA, the ABA is undertaking a number of activities intended to assist with the transition to new regulatory arrangements for on-line content announced by the Minister and the Attorney-General on 15 July 1997. These have included convening a Children and On-line Content Taskforce and the development of educational strategies. The Children and On-line Content Taskforce reported to the ABA in June 1998 and the government is considering the ABA's advice on these recommendations contained in its interim report on the inquiry into transitional arrangements. Encouraging families to use the internet was a key focus for Australia's first Online Australia Day held on 27 November 1998. This included the launch of a special website offering advice to parents on supervising internet use, tools available to screen material, links to sites developed for children, and other family information such as child accident prevention.

para.inline: The committee recommends that the Federal and State Governments increase, through the relevant departments, funding currently available to organisations that run conflict resolution programs and other programs designed to promote a culture of non-violence in the community.

interjection.para: The government expresses in-principle support for this recommendation but would need to consider any funding proposals from relevant agencies in the Budget context. The government notes activities of the States and Territories following the 1994 House of Representatives Standing Committee Report on Employment Education and Training Report on Violence in Australia Schools Sticks and Stones Report which targeted violence in schools.

The government notes in the area of domestic violence, the new Commonwealth, States and Territories initiative Partnerships Against Domestic Violence . Partnerships will test innovative approaches to domestic violence prevention. A major focus of Partnerships is community youth education strategies, for example, community organisations are being funded to develop and run domestic violence prevention workshops throughout Australia aimed at changing behaviours of young people aged 12-25 years, whose experience of domestic violence is as a victim or witness and will also assist young people who behave violently.

para.inline: The committee recommends that the ABA review the number of viewer complaints about the amount and levels of violence shown by a television network in order to:
(a) highlight those television networks showing the most violence
(b) encourage a reduction in violent programming by linking it to the commercial television licence renewing process.

interjection.para: This recommendation is a matter for the ABA to consider, in implementing its statutory functions to monitor compliance with industry codes of practice and renew broadcasting licences. The government understands that the ABA believes that attitudinal research techniques provide a better measure of indicators of viewers' concerns than do complaints because people are motivated to complain for different reasons, about different aspects of programs and this does not make their complaints easy to analyse or categorise according to their concerns.

However, while acknowledging that the ABA already publishes detailed information about complaints received, and has a range of sanctions available to it under the BSA to deal with breaches of codes and the BSA, the government would encourage broadcasters and the ABA to closely monitor complaints made about the violent content of programs, including complaints made by telephone which might not otherwise be taken into account in any analysis of public concerns. The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has written to the ABA asking it to be vigilant in monitoring the performance of the broadcasters against the codes of practice.
