subdebateinfo.title: Bureau of Air Safety Investigation: Trial Airspace
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 172)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 24 November 1998:

question.para: (1) Did the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation (BASI) undertake an investigation of the class G airspace trial procedures prior to the commencement of those trials; if so: (a) when did that review commence; (b) when was it completed; (c) what were the findings of the review; and (d) was a copy of the review report provided to the Minister.
(2) How many separation breakdowns or `incident reports' have been received by BASI since the trial commenced.
(3) (a) What was the nature of each incident; (b) when was each incident reported; and (c) what action was taken as a result of each report.
(4) Can copies be provided of all the incident reports to date.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) No

(2) The term `separation breakdown' refers to the breakdown of air traffic control separation standards. These standards apply only to operations within controlled airspace. For operations outside controlled airspace, similar events are described as `traffic conflictions'.
During the period of the Class `G' airspace demonstration, BASI received 160 reports relating to the airspace demonstration.
Sixteen of these reports were assessed as requiring further investigation and the remainder assessed as Category 5 occurrences.

Category 5 occurrences are those that are primarily of statistical interest and are recorded on the BASI database for future trend analysis. The information as reported to the Bureau is available to the public on request.
(3) (a) The sixteen incidents investigated involved actual or potential traffic conflictions or issues relating to the design and management of the demonstration.

One of these incidents was classified at the Category 3 level, which requires a preliminary report as well as a final report. The preliminary report for this occurrence was released on 4 December 1998 and a copy is attached.

Category 3 occurrences are those where the initial indications suggest potentially serious safety deficiencies. Consequently, an in-depth investigation is required to satisfy the concern for public safety. The report will include a Safety Action Statement detailing the relevant safety actions. Reports are available to the public on request.
(b) The incidents under investigation were reported during the period 22 October 1998 to 3 December 1998.

(c) In addition to the investigation of the sixteen incidents referred to above, on 5 November 1998, BASI commenced a systemic investigation of the Class G Airspace Demonstration. On 9 December BASI issued three Interim Recommendations, which resulted in the airspace demonstration ceasing on 13 December. Following the release of the Interim Recommendations the Minister announced that the Secretary of the Department of Transport and Regional Services was to conduct a review to ensure the safety integrity of the aviation system. The review will clarify the roles and responsibilities of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority, Airservices Australia and the Department in relation to the regulation, design and management of airspace.

(4) The preliminary report on the category 3 incident together with Brief Print (Public) reports of the other fifteen incidents investigated during the `G' airspace demonstration have been provided to the Table Office.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 24 November 1998:

question.para: (1) Does the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) International Standards and Recommended Practices (11th edition, July 1997) state in Annex 11 to the Convention on International Civil Aviation, section 4.2.2, that, `Flight information service provided to flights shall include . . . in addition to that outlined in 4.2.1, the provision of information concerning . . . collision hazards, to aircraft operating in airspace Classes C, D, E, F and G'.

(2) Can it be confirmed that before the commencement of the Class G airspace trials in the Ballina-Canberra corridor, Air Traffic Services of Airservices Australia provided a collision hazard alerting service in accordance with the ICAO Convention.

(3) Can it be confirmed that the Aeronautical Information Service document AIRAC-H48/98, dated 8 October 1998, and headed, `Extension of radar information services in Class G airspace and demonstration of the national advisory frequency' states at paragraph 8.1, that `The provision of a non-radar-based direct traffic information service to pilots of instrument flights rules and military low jet flights will be discontinued,' and at paragraph 9.1, that `During the demonstration, where radar coverage is available to the controller, air traffic control will provide a Radar Information Service (RIS) on a workload permitting basis to all flights and all phases of the flight,' and at paragraph 9.2 that, `Provision of this service is not optional on the part of the controller but will be done as the work situation permits,' and at paragraph 9.3 that, `Controllers possess complete discretion for determining whether they are able to provide this service in a specific case'.

(4) Are these arrangements for the Class G airspace trial in breach of Australia's obligations as set out in section 4.2.2 of the ICAO international standards and recommended practices because no such collision hazard alerting service is available to all aircraft.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Yes.

(2) Before the commencement of the Class G airspace trials in the Ballina-Canberra corridor, Air Traffic Services provided advice about other aircraft in the form of a procedural traffic information service to flights operating under the Instrument Flight Rules (IFR) and Military Low Jet (MLJ) aircraft about other conflicting IFR or MLJ aircraft.

Also, a Radar Advisory Service (RAS) was introduced in airspace around the Ballina/Casino/Lismore area to the south of Coolangatta, providing a traffic information and position information service, based primarily on radar derived data, to assist pilots in avoiding other aircraft, or to assist in pilot navigation.
(3) Yes.

(4) The provision of services in the demonstration airspace is consistent with the requirements of ICAO International Standards and Recommended Practices for Air Traffic Services (Annex 11 to the Convention on International Civil Aviation). The services provided in the demonstration Class G airspace changed from a directed, procedural traffic information service, generally relating to IFR and MLJ flights, to that of a Radar Information Service (RIS). Aeronautical Information Publication Supplement (AIP SUP) H48/98 explains that "During the demonstration, where radar coverage is available to the controller, air traffic control will provide a Radar Information Service (RIS) on a workload permitting basis to all flights and all phases of the flight."
Annex 11 (12th edition, July 1998) Note 1 to section 4.2.2 says:

"the information in b), including only known aircraft the presence of which might constitute a collision hazard to the aircraft informed, will sometimes be incomplete and air traffic services cannot assume responsibility at all times or for its accuracy."

Section 4.2.2 [as quoted in Question(1)]is interpreted by some as mandating the provision of a directed traffic information service as has been provided in Australian Class G airspace. This interpretation, however, is not shared by the Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) nor by administrations of other International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) States, eg. USA and Canada, neither of which provide such a service in Class G airspace.
In each of these countries, "known aircraft" is generally interpreted to mean aircraft which are visible to air traffic control, usually on radar.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 24 November 1998:

question.para: (1) How much of the new Class G airspace will be covered by radar at 5 000 feet.
(2) Can a chart be provided which indicates radar coverage at various altitudes in the proposed new Class G airspace.

(3) Did the Director of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority, Mr Mick Toller, advise the aviation industry at a meeting of the Regional Airspace Users Advisory Committee on 17 September 1998 that a radar information service (RIS) would be available on demand; if so, what was the basis of that advise.

(4) Did the Chief Executive of Airservices Australia, Mr Bill Pollard, advise the industry by way of a media release, dated 7 October 1998, that, `regional' airlines could be assured that the radar service they sought would be consistently available'; if so, what was the basis on which Mr Pollard made that commitment to the industry.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) More than 50% of G airspace at 5000ft was covered by radar during the trial.
(2) Yes. Airservices Australia can make the chart available to the Senator on request, but due to its nature, a copy cannot be provided in this context

(4) Yes. The quote attributed to Mr Pollard in the CASA media release of 7 October 1998 was in the context of aircraft operating within radar coverage. That is, aircraft operating within radar areas would receive a consistent service.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 24 November 1998:

question.para: (1) How do pilots flying in the new G class airspace access important information concerning weather conditions at departure, destination and alternate aerodromes.
(2) Are pilots flying in the new G class airspace required to monitor the national advisory frequency to detect other air traffic.
(3) Do these arrangements require pilots to continuously monitor two radio frequencies.

(4) (a) Does the ICAO document `Provision of Air Navigation ServicesâRegulation and Control', page 7-2, section 1.3.5.1 require that certain weather reports be `directed' to aircraft and, in addition, an immediate broadcast is required followed by `continuous or frequent broadcast' in some circumstances; and (b) how will Australia conform to that requirement in Class G airspace.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1)â(4) The changes to Class G airspace were part of a series of changes to Australian airspace to harmonise with international standards and were proposed by the Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) in August 1997.

The Bureau of Air Safety Investigation (BASI) conducted a systemic investigation of the Class G demonstration as part of its normal safety functions. BASI identified a number of safety concerns during its investigation and concluded that the demonstration had served its purpose and that it should now be subject to a comprehensive evaluation.

The Director of Aviation Safety of CASA, Mr Mick Toller, made a commitment that the demonstration would be cancelled if any genuine safety concerns were identified by CASA or BASI. Further to the BASI investigation, the demonstration of the new Class G airspace was terminated by CASA on 13 December 1998.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Maritime Safety Authority: Rescue of Fishing Vessel
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 181)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 24 November 1998:

question.para: (1) At what time was the Australian Maritime Safety Authority (AMSA) first advised of the fact that the fishing vessel Surprise, was in difficulty south of Strahan, Tasmania, on or around 7 April 1998.
(2) What was the registration and model of the aircraft that conducted the rescue.
(3) Where did the flight originate.
(4) (a)At what time was the company that operated the aircraft notified of the task; and (b) at what time did the aircraft depart.
(5) At what time did the aircraft arrive on the scene.
(6) What was the exact location of the rescue.
(7) Did AMSA consider the use of Precision Aerial Delivery System equipment; if not, why not.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question. It should be noted however, that with the exception of Part 4(b), Senator O'Brien asked these questions following the Senate Estimates hearing on 5 June 1998. Answers to these questions are the same as those provided for Senator O'Brien in June.

answer.para: (1) At 3.00 pm on Thursday 09 April 1998, a possible Emergency Position Indicating Radio Beacon (EPIRB) signal was detected by the COSPAS-SARSAT satellite system. A further satellite pass at 4.03 pm confirmed that a beacon signal was being transmitted from approximately 60 nautical miles south of Strahan, south west Tasmania. AMSA arranged a fixed wing search aircraft through the air charter company "Wilderness Air" of Strahan. That aircraft arrived at the scene at approximately 5.30 pm and sighted a liferaft drifting slowly towards shore in the Nye Bay area, thus confirming that a distress situation existed.

(2) A helicopter, arranged by AMSA for the rescue effort, was an AS50 Squirrel, registration VH-SES. A second helicopter, arranged by AMSA for a night search, was a Bell 412, registration VH-NSP (call sign Helimed 1)
(3) The rescue helicopter departed from Cambridge Airfield in Tasmania. The second helicopter departed from Latrobe Valley in Victoria.
(4) (a) The rescue helicopter was arranged at 4.17 pm through the Hobart Police Headquarters. The second helicopter was arranged at 6.30pm.
(b) The rescue helicopter departed Cambridge Airfield at 4.56 pm. The second helicopter departed Latrobe Valley at approximately 7.20 pm.
(5) The rescue helicopter arrived on scene approximately 6.00pm. The second helicopter arrived on scene at approximately 11.30pm.
(6) The location of the raft was at position 43 03S 145 40E in Nye Bay in inshore waters. The survivor was able to reach the shore to meet the helicopter.

(7) No. At the time of the incident, AMSA did not have available any operational PADS equip ment, nor personnel trained in the use of PADS equipment. Further, there was no call for the use of any air-droppable supplies as the survivor from the incident was located already in a life raft and the second crew member, who potentially could have benefited from air-droppable supplies, was never sighted.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Maritime Safety Authority: Aerial Rescue Delivery System
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 182)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 24 November 1998:

question.para: (1) Is the Australian Maritime Safety Authority satisfied with the performance of the Aerial Rescue Delivery System (ARDS)/ Precision Aerial Delivery System (PADS).
(2) Is ARDS/PADS fully operational.
(3) On how many occasions has the equipment been deployed.

(4) Are there any restrictions on its use; if so: (a) what is the nature of each of these restrictions; and (b) have they been imposed as a result of testing of the equipment or problems detected in the deployment of the equipment.
(5) Can copies be provided of all reports into the use of this equipment that led to limitations being imposed on its use.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) AMSA considers that PADS Series G delivers emergency supplies more accurately and efficiently than the traditional delivery systems used in Australia.

(2) AMSA is currently deploying PADS Series G to eight locations around Australia and expects the deployment and training of personnel at these locations to be completed by 10 December 1998. The final distribution of this equipment will be considered when the current review of air-droppable supplies has been finalised.

(3) As at the 30 November 1998, PADS Series G has not been used in an operational search and rescue incident, but AMSA has deployed the equipment on approximately 160 occasions during training and aircraft certification sessions.
(4) As at 30 November 1998, AMSA has placed no restrictions on the use of PADS Series G equipment.

subdebateinfo.title: Civil Aviation Safety Authority: Air Traffic Control Standards
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 184)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 24 November 1998:

question.para: (1) Has the Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) formed a group to devise air traffic control (ATC) standards and regulations for third party ATC providers: if so, what are the composition, background and qualifications of the group.
(2) When did the work commence and when is it scheduled for completion.
(3) What are the terms of reference for the project.
(4) What consultation will be undertaken with industrial organisations, the aviation industry and the public.
(5) (a) What form will the standards or regulations take; and (b) will they be in the form of civil aviation regulations, air navigation orders or some other form.
(6) Will CASA determine the hours of operation for the ATC service at each location or will these be determined by the ATC provider.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) As noted in the Minister for Transport and Regional Services' response to Question on Notice No. 171, the Government has agreed to consider introducing competition into some aspects of Airservices' tower businesses, but not until CASA has developed appropriate operating and licensing standards for all air traffic control operations.

To progress the development of these standards the Department of Transport and Regional Services (DOTRS) has constituted an Air Traffic Services (ATS) Working Group. The group is led by one of CASA's Associate Directors and comprises members from CASA, Airservices Australia, DOTRS and Defence, as appropriate.

The background and qualifications of the group encompass technical expertise in air traffic control operations, regulatory standards development in the air traffic control area, past air traffic controllers and officers with relevant government policy in the aviation industry.
(2) The work of the group commenced in September 1998 and is currently scheduled for completion by end June 1999.
(3) The key issues to be addressed by the ATS Working Group are:
(c) develop establishment/disestablishment criteria for tower air traffic services. The provision of a tower service to be the responsibility of the airport owner/lessee; and

(b) develop minimum operating standards and licensing requirements for the provision of air traffic services. These standards should encapsulate other related services such as the provision of aeronautical information and telecommunication services.

(4) Once the appropriate regulatory framework has been developed CASA will be exposing the proposed framework, and inviting comment on it, from the aviation industry, industrial organisations and the public through its normal Notice of Proposed Rule Making (NPRM) process.
(5) (a) The standards to be developed will take the form of Civil Aviation Regulations.
(b) See (a).

6. It is expected that any variation to the hours of operation of an individual tower ATC service would be determined on a case by case basis through consultations between the airport owner, the ATC provider/s and users, with final approval to any change agreed by CASA in accordance with the appropriate standards.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Advanced Air Traffic System: Air Traffic Controllers Recommendations
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 190)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 24 November 1998:

question.para: (1) Did the majority of air traffic controllers interviewed recommend that the Australian Advanced Air Traffic System (TAAATS) radar system should not be commissioned in the airspace of the Sydney terminal area until after the Olympics.
(2) What action has Airservices Australia taken in response to this recommendation.

(3) Is the Minister aware that the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation stated in its report, Systemic investigation into factors underlying air safety occurrences in Sydney terminal area airspace, that: Eighty percent of the Sydney controllers reported being overwhelmed by the volume and complexity of some of temporary local instructions, some of which had been promulgated with minimum lead times.

A number (of controllers) admitted that they did not always read or absorb the information contained in the (instructions) and often relied on other controllers or the shift team leader to brief them when necessary.
(4) What action has been taken, or is planned, to reduce the rate of change to a more manageable rate.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Yes.

(2) The views of air traffic controllers on the timing of TAAATS commissioning in the Sydney terminal area were recorded in the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation (BASI) report on a Systemic Investigation into Factors Underlying Air Safety Occurrences in the Sydney Terminal Area Airspace. It is more important that Airservices Australia respond to BASI recommendations formulated as a result of the overall investigation rather than to the many views and opinions recorded in the body of the report. In that context BASI did recommend that Airservices Australia review its change management procedures and the program for change leading up to the Olympics. The review should ensure that safety is not compromised to meet project schedules or perceived community imperatives. Airservices is developing its response to this BASI recommendation in consultation with the Bureau.
(3) Yes.

(4) Airservices continuously monitors the introduction of new procedures and processes to ensure that the operational impact of that change is well managed. The program of change in Sydney has been extensively reviewed with changes being prioritised to ensure that safety is not compromised whilst maintaining the implementation schedule for TAAATS. For example, training for TAAATS has been postponed until 1999 and Sydney Long Term Operating Plan (LTOP) Mode 8 has been deferred until mid 1999 and Mode 6A until late 1999.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Advanced Air Traffic System: Transport and Regional Services
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 192)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 24 November 1998:

question.para: (1) What was the outcome of the action brought by Hughes Aircraft Corporation over their loss of the Australian Advanced Air Traffic System (TAAATS) contract.
(2) Is TAAATS operating at Cairns and in the airspace surrounding Cairns; if so, when did the operation of the new system commence.
(3) Has Airservices Australia conducted any survey of the staff using the new system; if so, what were the results from the survey; if not, when will such a survey be carried out.
(4) If Airservices Australia does not plan to conduct such a survey, why not.
(5) Have air traffic controllers found the human machine interface (HMI) cumbersome and very user unfriendly.
(6) What action does Airservices Australia plan to take to address this particular problem.
(7) Have there been any problems with screen reflections and flicker causing health problems for air traffic controllers using TAAATS equipment.
(8) What action has Airservices Australia taken, or what action does it plan to take, to address this particular problem.
(9) Is sick leave increasing on the sectors using TAAATS equipment compared to when this group of controllers were using non-TAAATS equipment.
(10) Can a copy be provided of sick leave statistics relating to these two periods.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Liability has been determined in favour of Hughes Aircraft Corporation. The damages action is still being heard in the Federal Court.
(2) Yes. TAAATS operations commenced on 8 August 1998 with full 24 hour operations being achieved on 22 August 1998.

(3) A post commissioning review involved the collection of information on how the transitioning process could be improved. Staff views were canvassed in workshops and through individual contributions. Major improvements arising from the review include just in time training for commissioning, staffing aspects of commissioning, improvements to software, commissioning processes and their management.
(4) See Question 3

(5) The TAAATS HMI is a very different way of performing the work of air traffic control. The experience to date is that the level of concern diminishes with more extensive operational experience in using the new system.

(6) Airservices established initial operations in Cairns and surrounding sectors specifically as a pilot program with the objective of using this experience to assist with the overall program. Each phase of commissioning will be reviewed. Experience gained will be used to improve operational practices. Software changes have been commis sioned based on such experiences to assist the remainder of the commissioning program.

(7) Overhead map lights and ceiling lights have caused reflections off the TAAATS screens. Screen flicker was perceived by some staff as a problem. A small number of staff have gone off duty early because of headaches they associated with screen flicker.

(8) Screen reflections are being managed by modifying the lighting diffusers in the operations room, setting lighting levels at a fixed value and trialing the adjustment of the angle of tilt of the screens. These attenuate the amount of reflected light from the ceiling.
The screen flicker has been managed by defining the screen background colour and lighting settings

to minimise the perception of flicker. Lighter colours highlight the perception of flicker and the colour palette has been selected to avoid the use of such colours. However, there is a wide range of sensitivity to flicker and no single, simple solution.
Both reflection and flicker have been managed with the assistance of expert advice and will continue to be monitored and further corrective action will be taken as appropriate.
(9) There is no evidence to suggest that air traffic controller sick leave in the TAAATS environment is any different from that which occurred pre-TAAATS.
(10) Airservices can make available to the Senator aggregate sick leave statistics relating to the periods concerned.
